Questions: How does the Gita start?
Answers: Its branches spread below and above, nourished by the Gunas; its buds are sense-objects, and its roots stretch forth below in the world of men, originating action.

Questions: How does the Gita start?
Answers: All beings, O Arjuna, go into My Nature at the end of a Kalpa; I send them forth again at the beginning of the next Kalpa.

Questions: How does the Gita start?
Answers: Then, Arjuna, filled with wonder and his hair standing on end, bowed his head to the God and spoke with palms joined.

Questions: How does the Gita start?
Answers: With the mind not moving towards any other thing, made steadfast through the practice of habitual meditation, and constantly meditating, one goes to the Supreme Person, the Resplendent, O Arjuna.

Questions: How does the Gita start?
Answers: Under Me, as supervisor, Nature produces the moving and the unmoving; therefore, O Arjuna, the world revolves.

Questions: How does the Gita start?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, place my chariot in the middle between the two armies, so that I may behold those who stand here, desirous to fight, and know with whom I must fight when the battle is about to commence."

Questions: How does the Gita start?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, place my chariot in the middle between the two armies, so that I may behold those who stand here, desirous to fight, and know with whom I must fight when the battle is about to commence."

Questions: How does the Gita start?
Answers: Arjuna said, "He who is unable to control himself, even though he has faith, and whose mind wanders away from Yoga, what end does he meet, having failed to attain perfection in Yoga, O Krishna?"

Questions: How does the Gita start?
Answers: Arjuna said, "Later was Thy birth, and prior to it was the birth of Vivasvan (the Sun); how am I to understand that Thou hast taught this Yoga from the beginning?"

Questions: How does the Gita start?
Answers: Then, seeing the people of Dhritarashtra's party standing arrayed and the discharge of weapons about to begin, Arjuna, the son of Pandu whose ensign was a monkey, took up his bow and said the following to Krishna, O Lord of the Earth.

Questions: How does the Gita start?
Answers: Drona, Bhishma, Jayadratha, Karna, and other brave warriors have already been slain by Me; do not be distressed with fear; fight and you shall conquer your enemies in battle.

Questions: In the Mahabharata war, whom did Duryodhana first talk to?
Answers: For I desire to observe those who are assembled here to fight, wishing to please in battle the evil-minded Duryodhana—the son of Dhritarashtra.

Questions: In the Mahabharata war, whom did Duryodhana first talk to?
Answers: His glorious grandsire, the oldest of the Kauravas, roared like a lion to cheer Duryodhana and blew his conch.

Questions: In the Mahabharata war, whom did Duryodhana first talk to?
Answers: Hrishikesha blew the Panchajanya, Arjuna blew the Devadatta, and Bhima, the wolf-bellied doer of terrible deeds, blew the great conch Paundra.

Questions: In the Mahabharata war, whom did Duryodhana first talk to?
Answers: Sanjaya said: Having spoken thus to Hrishikesha, the Lord of the senses, Arjuna, the conqueror of sleep and destroyer of foes, said, "I will not fight," and became silent.

Questions: In the Mahabharata war, whom did Duryodhana first talk to?
Answers: Dhritarashtra said, "What did my people and the sons of Pandu do when they had assembled together, eager for battle, on the holy plain of Kurukshetra, O Sanjaya?"

Questions: In the Mahabharata war, whom did Duryodhana first talk to?
Answers: To him who was despondent in the midst of the two armies, Krishna, smiling, O Bharata, spoke these words.

Questions: In the Mahabharata war, whom did Duryodhana first talk to?
Answers: All the sons of Dhritarashtra, along with the hosts of kings of the earth, Bhishma, Drona, and Karna, as well as the chief among our warriors.

Questions: In the Mahabharata war, whom did Duryodhana first talk to?
Answers: He saw fathers-in-law and friends in both the armies. The son of Kunti, Arjuna, seeing all those kinsmen thus standing arrayed, spoke sorrowfully, deeply filled with pity.

Questions: In the Mahabharata war, whom did Duryodhana first talk to?
Answers: Then, Arjuna (son of Pritha) saw there (in the armies) stationed fathers, grandfathers, teachers, maternal uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons, and friends.

Questions: What did Duryodhana say to his teacher, Drona?

Questions: What did Duryodhana say to his teacher, Drona?

Questions: What did Duryodhana say to his teacher, Drona?

Questions: What did Duryodhana say to his teacher, Drona?

Questions: What did Duryodhana say to his teacher, Drona?

Questions: What was Krishna's first reaction on seeing the grief stricken state of Arjuna?

Questions: What was Krishna's first reaction on seeing the grief stricken state of Arjuna?

Questions: What was Krishna's first reaction on seeing the grief stricken state of Arjuna?

Questions: Is it suitable for wise people to grieve?
Answers: And now, O Arjuna, hear from Me of the threefold pleasure, in which one rejoices through practice and surely comes to the end of pain.

Questions: Is it suitable for wise people to grieve?
Answers: Indifference to the objects of the senses and also absence of egoism; perceiving the evil in birth, death, old age, sickness, and pain.

Questions: Is it suitable for wise people to grieve?
Answers: Endowed with a pure intellect, controlling the self through firmness, relinquishing sound and other objects and abandoning attraction and hatred.

Questions: Is it suitable for wise people to grieve?
Answers: That person attains peace who, abandoning all desires, moves about without longing, without the sense of ownership, and without egoism.

Questions: Is it suitable for wise people to grieve?
Answers: These qualities, O Arjuna, born of Nature, bind fast in the body of the embodied, the indestructible: purity, passion, and inertia.

Questions: Is it suitable for wise people to grieve?
Answers: That happiness which arises from the contact of the senses with the objects, which is initially like nectar but eventually like poison, is said to be Rajasic.

Questions: Is it suitable for wise people to grieve?
Answers: Those who long for success in action in this world sacrifice to the gods; for success is quickly attained by men through action.

Questions: Is it suitable for wise people to grieve?
Answers: When, like the tortoise which withdraws all its limbs on all sides, he withdraws his senses from the sense-objects, then his wisdom becomes steady.

Questions: Is it suitable for wise people to grieve?
Answers: The Supreme Self of him who is self-controlled and peaceful remains balanced in cold and heat, pleasure and pain, as well as in honor and dishonor.

Questions: Is it suitable for wise people to grieve?
Answers: Just as the embodied soul passes through childhood, youth, and old age in this body, so too does it pass into another body; the steadfast one does not grieve over this.

Questions: Do human beings cease to exist when they die?

Questions: Do human beings cease to exist when they die?

Questions: Do human beings cease to exist when they die?
Answers: The contact of the senses with the objects, O son of Kunti, which causes heat and cold, pleasure and pain, has a beginning and an end; they are impermanent; endure them bravely, O Arjuna.

Questions: Do human beings cease to exist when they die?
Answers: Tell me again in detail, O Krishna, of your yogic power and glory; for I am not satiated with what I have heard of your life-giving and nectar-like speech.

Questions: Do human beings cease to exist when they die?
Answers: Arjuna said, "It is fitting, O Krishna, that the world delights and rejoices in Your praise; demons fly in fear in all directions and the hosts of the perfected ones bow to You."

Questions: Do human beings cease to exist when they die?
Answers: Sanjaya said: To him, who was thus overcome with pity, despondent, with eyes full of tears and agitated, Madhusudana (the destroyer of Madhu) or Krishna spoke these words.

Questions: Do human beings cease to exist when they die?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, I do not see how this Yoga of equanimity, which you have taught me, can be maintained steadily, due to the restlessness of the mind."

Questions: Do human beings cease to exist when they die?
Answers: Arjuna said, "Having seen this Thy gentle human form, O Krishna, now I am composed and have been restored to my own nature."

Questions: Do human beings cease to exist when they die?
Answers: O King, remembering this wonderful and holy dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna, I continually rejoice.

Questions: Do human beings cease to exist when they die?
Answers:
I desire not victory, O Krishna, nor kingdom, nor pleasures.
What use is dominion to us, O Krishna, or pleasures or even life?

Questions: What happens to the soul or Atman after death of the body?
Answers: Nor do beings exist in Me (in reality); behold, My divine Yoga, which supports all beings, but does not dwell in them, is My Self, the efficient cause of beings.

Questions: What happens to the soul or Atman after death of the body?
Answers: Those who worship the imperishable, the indefinable, the unmanifest, the omnipresent, the unthinkable, the immovable, and the eternal.

Questions: What happens to the soul or Atman after death of the body?
Answers: It is within and without all beings, both the unmoving and the moving; It is subtle and unknowable, and It is near and far away.

Questions: What happens to the soul or Atman after death of the body?
Answers: This is the royal science, the royal secret, the supreme purifier, realizable by direct intuitive knowledge, according to righteousness, very easy to perform and imperishable.

Questions: What happens to the soul or Atman after death of the body?
Answers: What is known as the Unmanifested and the Imperishable, That is said to be the highest goal. Those who reach It do not return (to this Samsara). That is My supreme abode (place or state).

Questions: What happens to the soul or Atman after death of the body?
Answers: Even here in this world, those whose minds rest in reality overcome birth; Brahman is indeed spotless and real; therefore they are established in Brahman.

Questions: What happens to the soul or Atman after death of the body?
Answers: The foolish think of Me, the Unmanifest, as having manifestation, not knowing My higher, immutable, and most excellent nature.

Questions: What happens to the soul or Atman after death of the body?
Answers: I see You without beginning, middle, or end, infinite in power, with endless arms, the sun and moon as Your eyes, the burning fire Your mouth, heating the entire universe with Your radiance.

Questions: What happens to the soul or Atman after death of the body?
Answers: They are possessed of the deceitful nature of demons and undivine beings, filled with vain hopes, vain actions, and vain knowledge that is senseless.

Questions: What happens to the soul or Atman after death of the body?
Answers: They say, "This universe is without truth, without a moral basis, without a God, brought about by mutual union, with lust as its cause; what else?"

Questions: What happens to the soul or Atman after death of the body?
Answers: For I am the abode of Brahman, the immortal, immutable, and everlasting Dharma, and absolute bliss.

Questions: Does the soul transmigrate after death of the body?
Answers: But distinct is the Supreme Purusha, called the highest Self, indestructible and Lord, who pervades the three worlds and sustains them.

Questions: Does the soul transmigrate after death of the body?

Questions: Does the soul transmigrate after death of the body?
Answers: For I am the abode of Brahman, the immortal, immutable, and everlasting Dharma, and absolute bliss.

Questions: Does the soul transmigrate after death of the body?

Questions: Does the soul transmigrate after death of the body?

Questions: Does the soul transmigrate after death of the body?

Answers: It is not born, nor does it ever die; after having been, it again does not cease to be; unborn, eternal, changeless, and ancient, it is not killed when the body is killed.

Questions: What is transmigration of the soul?

Questions: What is transmigration of the soul?
Answers: Whoever at the end leaves the body, thinking of any being, to that being only does he go, O son of Kunti (Arjuna), due to his constant thought of that being.

Questions: What is transmigration of the soul?

Questions: What is transmigration of the soul?
Answers: Whoever knows it to be indestructible, eternal, unborn, and inexhaustible, how can that person slay, O Arjuna, or cause to be slain?

Questions: What is transmigration of the soul?

Questions: What is transmigration of the soul?

Questions: What is transmigration of the soul?
Answers: Constancy in Self-knowledge, the perception of the end of true knowledge—this is declared to be knowledge, and what is opposed to it is ignorance.

Questions: What is transmigration of the soul?
Answers: That by which one sees the indestructible Reality in all beings, not separate in any of them—know that knowledge to be Sattvic.

Questions: What are the properties of the soul or atman?

Questions: What are the properties of the soul or atman?

Questions: What happens to the self after death?
Answers: Among creations I am the beginning, the middle, and the end, O Arjuna; among the sciences, I am the science of the Self; and I am the logic among controversialists.

Questions: What happens to the self after death?

Answers: And whoever, leaving their body, goes forth remembering Me alone at the time of death, they will attain My Being; there is no doubt about this.

Questions: Who am I?
Answers: All of this world is pervaded by Me in My unmanifest aspect; all beings exist within Me, but I do not dwell within them.

Questions: Who am I?
Answers: I am the Self, O Gudakesa, seated in the hearts of all beings; I am the beginning, the middle, and the end of all beings.

Questions: Who am I?
Answers: Prowess, splendor, firmness, dexterity, and not fleeing from battle, generosity, and lordliness are the duties of the Kshatriyas, born of their own nature.

Questions: Who am I?

Questions: Can you explain the cycle of birth and death?
Answers: Thus, knowing Him who is superior to the intellect and restraining the self by the Self, slay thou, O mighty-armed Arjuna, the enemy in the form of desire, hard to conquer.

Questions: Do beings have a definite beginning and end?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "O Arjuna, neither in this world nor in the next will there be destruction for him; none, indeed, who does good, O my son, ever comes to grief."

Questions: Do beings have a definite beginning and end?
Answers: Sanjaya said: Having spoken thus to Hrishikesha, the Lord of the senses, Arjuna, the conqueror of sleep and destroyer of foes, said, "I will not fight," and became silent.

Questions: Do beings have a definite beginning and end?
Answers: He saw fathers-in-law and friends in both the armies. The son of Kunti, Arjuna, seeing all those kinsmen thus standing arrayed, spoke sorrowfully, deeply filled with pity.

Questions: Do beings have a definite beginning and end?
Answers: Then, seeing the people of Dhritarashtra's party standing arrayed and the discharge of weapons about to begin, Arjuna, the son of Pandu whose ensign was a monkey, took up his bow and said the following to Krishna, O Lord of the Earth.

Questions: Do beings have a definite beginning and end?
Answers: Hrishikesha blew the Panchajanya, Arjuna blew the Devadatta, and Bhima, the wolf-bellied doer of terrible deeds, blew the great conch Paundra.

Questions: Do beings have a definite beginning and end?
Answers: Then, Arjuna (son of Pritha) saw there (in the armies) stationed fathers, grandfathers, teachers, maternal uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons, and friends.

Questions: Do beings have a definite beginning and end?
Answers: Soon he becomes righteous and attains eternal peace; O Arjuna, proclaim thou for certain that My devotee never perishes.

Questions: Do beings have a definite beginning and end?
Answers: Sanjaya said, Having thus spoken to Arjuna, Krishna again showed His own form. The great Soul, assuming His gentle form, then consoled Arjuna, who was terrified.

Questions: Do beings have a definite beginning and end?
Answers: Thus, knowing Him who is superior to the intellect and restraining the self by the Self, slay thou, O mighty-armed Arjuna, the enemy in the form of desire, hard to conquer.

Questions: Do beings have a definite beginning and end?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, Again, O mighty-armed Arjuna, listen to my supreme word which I will declare to you, who are beloved, for your welfare.

Questions: Do beings have a definite beginning and end?
Answers: Arjuna said, "But what compels man to commit sin, even against his wishes, O Varshneya (Krishna), as if constrained by force?"

Questions: What is so wonderful about the soul or the self?
Answers: Soon he becomes righteous and attains eternal peace; O Arjuna, proclaim thou for certain that My devotee never perishes.

Questions: What is so wonderful about the soul or the self?
Answers: He who does not follow the wheel thus set in motion, who is of sinful life, rejoicing in the senses, lives in vain, O Arjuna.

Questions: What is so wonderful about the soul or the self?
Answers: Thus, knowing Him who is superior to the intellect and restraining the self by the Self, slay thou, O mighty-armed Arjuna, the enemy in the form of desire, hard to conquer.

Questions: What is so wonderful about the soul or the self?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "O Arjuna, neither in this world nor in the next will there be destruction for him; none, indeed, who does good, O my son, ever comes to grief."

Questions: What is so wonderful about the soul or the self?
Answers: One should not, O Arjuna, abandon the duty to which one is born, though it may be faulty; for, all undertakings are enveloped by evil, just as fire is by smoke.

Questions: What is so wonderful about the soul or the self?
Answers: One should not, O Arjuna, abandon the duty to which one is born, though it may be faulty; for, all undertakings are enveloped by evil, just as fire is by smoke.

Questions: What is so wonderful about the soul or the self?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, Again, O mighty-armed Arjuna, listen to my supreme word which I will declare to you, who are beloved, for your welfare.

Questions: What is so wonderful about the soul or the self?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "Undoubtedly, O mighty-armed Arjuna, the mind is difficult to control and restless; but with practice and dispassion, it can be restrained."

Questions: What is so wonderful about the soul or the self?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "O Arjuna, hear how you shall, without doubt, know Me fully, with your mind intent on Me, practicing Yoga and taking refuge in Me."

Questions: What is so wonderful about the soul or the self?
Answers: Through the grace of Vyasa, I have heard this supreme and most secret Yoga, directly from Krishna, the Lord of Yoga, Himself declaring it.

Questions: What is so wonderful about the soul or the self?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, I do not see how this Yoga of equanimity, which you have taught me, can be maintained steadily, due to the restlessness of the mind."

Questions: Are all the selves eternal and indestructible?
Answers: Arjuna said, "He who is unable to control himself, even though he has faith, and whose mind wanders away from Yoga, what end does he meet, having failed to attain perfection in Yoga, O Krishna?"

Questions: Are all the selves eternal and indestructible?
Answers: Arjuna said, "Later was Thy birth, and prior to it was the birth of Vivasvan (the Sun); how am I to understand that Thou hast taught this Yoga from the beginning?"

Questions: Are all the selves eternal and indestructible?
Answers: But whoever, controlling the senses by the mind, O Arjuna, engages himself in Karma Yoga with the organs of action, without attachment, he excels.

Questions: Are all the selves eternal and indestructible?
Answers: That place which is reached by the Sankhyas or the Jnanis is also reached by the Yogis (Karma Yogis). He who sees knowledge and the performance of action (Karma Yoga) as one, sees truly.

Questions: Are all the selves eternal and indestructible?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, you praise renunciation of actions and also yoga. Please tell me conclusively which is better of the two."

Questions: Are all the selves eternal and indestructible?
Answers: By that same former practice, he is borne on in spite of himself. Even he who merely wishes to know Yoga goes beyond the Brahmanic word.

Questions: Are all the selves eternal and indestructible?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "O Arjuna, hear how you shall, without doubt, know Me fully, with your mind intent on Me, practicing Yoga and taking refuge in Me."

Questions: Are all the selves eternal and indestructible?
Answers: Endowed with wisdom and evenness of mind, one casts off in this life both good and evil deeds; therefore, devote yourself to Yoga; Yoga is skill in action.

Questions: Are all the selves eternal and indestructible?
Answers: Endowed with wisdom and evenness of mind, one casts off in this life both good and evil deeds; therefore, devote yourself to Yoga; Yoga is skill in action.

Questions: Are all the selves eternal and indestructible?
Answers: Endowed with wisdom and evenness of mind, one casts off in this life both good and evil deeds; therefore, devote yourself to Yoga; Yoga is skill in action.

Questions: Are all the selves eternal and indestructible?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "In My opinion, those who fix their minds on Me, worship Me ever steadfastly, and are endowed with supreme faith, are the best in Yoga."

Questions: What is the greatest duty of a Kshatriya warrior?
Answers: Through the grace of Vyasa, I have heard this supreme and most secret Yoga, directly from Krishna, the Lord of Yoga, Himself declaring it.

Questions: What is the greatest duty of a Kshatriya warrior?
Answers: By that same former practice, he is borne on in spite of himself. Even he who merely wishes to know Yoga goes beyond the Brahmanic word.

Questions: What is the greatest duty of a Kshatriya warrior?
Answers: But whoever, controlling the senses by the mind, O Arjuna, engages himself in Karma Yoga with the organs of action, without attachment, he excels.

Questions: What is the greatest duty of a Kshatriya warrior?
Answers: When a person is not attached to the sense-objects or to actions, having renounced all thoughts, then they are said to have attained Yoga.

Questions: What is the greatest duty of a Kshatriya warrior?
Answers: Nor do beings exist in Me (in reality); behold, My divine Yoga, which supports all beings, but does not dwell in them, is My Self, the efficient cause of beings.

Questions: What is the greatest duty of a Kshatriya warrior?
Answers: That same ancient yoga has been today taught to you by me, for you are my devotee and my friend; it is the supreme secret.

Questions: What is the greatest duty of a Kshatriya warrior?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, I do not see how this Yoga of equanimity, which you have taught me, can be maintained steadily, due to the restlessness of the mind."

Questions: What is the greatest duty of a Kshatriya warrior?
Answers: In this, there is no loss of effort, nor is there any harm produced, nor any transgression. Even a little of this knowledge protects one from great fear.

Questions: What is the greatest duty of a Kshatriya warrior?
Answers: Without hope, controlling the mind and the self, having abandoned all covetousness, and performing only bodily actions, one incurs no sin.

Questions: What is the greatest duty of a Kshatriya warrior?
Answers: Do not be afraid, nor be bewildered on seeing such a terrible form of Mine; with your fear dispelled and with a gladdened heart, now behold again this former form of Mine.

Questions: What is the greatest duty of a Kshatriya warrior?
Answers: On seeing Thee, touching the sky, shining in many colors, with mouths wide open, with large fiery eyes, I am terrified at heart and find neither courage nor peace, O Vishnu.

Questions: What leads a Kshatriya warrior to heaven?
Answers: I am delighted, having seen something never seen before; yet my mind is distressed with fear. Show me that form only, O God; have mercy, O God of gods, O Abode of the universe.

Questions: What leads a Kshatriya warrior to heaven?
Answers: Dwelling in solitude, eating sparingly, with speech, body, and mind subdued, always engaged in meditation and concentration, and resorting to dispassion.

Questions: What leads a Kshatriya warrior to heaven?
Answers: Having closed all the gates, confined the mind in the heart, and fixed the life-breath in the head, engage in the practice of concentration.

Questions: What leads a Kshatriya warrior to heaven?
Answers: Having closed all the gates, confined the mind in the heart, and fixed the life-breath in the head, engage in the practice of concentration.

Questions: What leads a Kshatriya warrior to heaven?
Answers: Having seen Your immeasurable form with many mouths and eyes, O mighty-armed one, with many arms, thighs, and feet, with many stomachs and fearsome with many teeth, the worlds are terrified, and so am I.

Questions: What leads a Kshatriya warrior to heaven?
Answers: Renouncing all actions in Me, with the mind centered on the Self, free from hope and egoism, and from mental fever, fight thou.

Questions: What leads a Kshatriya warrior to heaven?
Answers: The yogi, always engaging the mind thus (in the practice of yoga), is freed from sins and easily enjoys the infinite bliss of contact with Brahman (the Eternal).

Questions: What leads a Kshatriya warrior to heaven?
Answers: The yogi is thought to be superior to the ascetics, even superior to those who have knowledge obtained through the study of scriptures; he is also superior to men of action; therefore, be thou a yogi, O Arjuna.

Questions: What leads a Kshatriya warrior to heaven?
Answers: That place which is reached by the Sankhyas or the Jnanis is also reached by the Yogis (Karma Yogis). He who sees knowledge and the performance of action (Karma Yoga) as one, sees truly.

Questions: What leads a Kshatriya warrior to heaven?
Answers: When he (the Yogi) feels that infinite bliss which can be grasped by the pure intellect and which transcends the senses, and is established therein, never moving away from the reality.

Questions: What leads a Kshatriya warrior to heaven?
Answers: He who, through the likeness of the Self, O Arjuna, sees reality everywhere, be it pleasure or pain, is regarded as the highest Yogi.

Questions: What happens to Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?
Answers: But whoever, controlling the senses by the mind, O Arjuna, engages himself in Karma Yoga with the organs of action, without attachment, he excels.

Questions: What happens to Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?
Answers: He who is able, while still here in this world, to withstand the impulse born out of desire and anger before the liberation from the body, he is a Yogi, and he is a happy man.

Questions: What happens to Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?
Answers: He who is able, while still here in this world, to withstand the impulse born out of desire and anger before the liberation from the body, he is a Yogi, and he is a happy man.

Questions: What happens to Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?
Answers: He who is able, while still here in this world, to withstand the impulse born out of desire and anger before the liberation from the body, he is a Yogi, and he is a happy man.

Questions: What happens to Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?
Answers: He who is able, while still here in this world, to withstand the impulse born out of desire and anger before the liberation from the body, he is a Yogi, and he is a happy man.

Questions: What happens to Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?
Answers: The knowers of the three Vedas, the drinkers of Soma, purified of all sins, worshipping Me through sacrifices, pray for the way to heaven; they reach the holy world of the Lord of the gods and enjoy the divine pleasures of the gods in heaven.

Questions: What happens to Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?
Answers: They, having enjoyed the vast heaven, enter the world of mortals when their merit is exhausted; thus abiding by the injunctions of the three (Vedas) and desiring objects of desires, they attain to the state of coming and going.

Questions: What happens to Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?
Answers: Others again sacrifice all the functions of the senses and those of the breath (vital energy, or Prana) in the fire of the Yoga of self-restraint, kindled by knowledge.

Questions: What happens to Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?
Answers: To the Brahmana who has known the Self, all the Vedas are of as much use as a reservoir of water would be in a place where there is a flood.

Questions: What happens to Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?
Answers: By these evil deeds of the destroyers of the family, which cause confusion of castes, the eternal religious rites of the caste and the family are destroyed.

Questions: What happens to Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?
Answers: When a person sees all beings as resting in the One and emanating from the One alone, they then become Brahman.

Questions: What do people treat Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?
Answers: The Vedas deal with the three attributes; be thou above these three attributes. O Arjuna, free yourself from the pairs of opposites and ever remain in the quality of Sattva, freed from acquisition and preservation, and be established in the Self.

Questions: What do people treat Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?
Answers: Confusion of castes leads to hell for the slayers of the family, for their forebears fall, deprived of the offerings of rice-balls and libations of water.

Questions: What do people treat Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?
Answers: Those who eat the remnants of the sacrifice, which are like nectar, go to the eternal Brahman. This world is not for the one who does not perform sacrifice; how then can they have the other, O Arjuna?

Questions: What do people treat Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?
Answers: And I am seated in the hearts of all; from Me come memory and knowledge, as well as their absence. I am verily That which has to be known by all the Vedas; I am indeed the author of the Vedanta and the knower of the Vedas.

Questions: What do people treat Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?
Answers: The knowers of the three Vedas, the drinkers of Soma, purified of all sins, worshipping Me through sacrifices, pray for the way to heaven; they reach the holy world of the Lord of the gods and enjoy the divine pleasures of the gods in heaven.

Questions: What do people treat Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?

Questions: What do people treat Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?

Questions: What do people treat Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?
Answers: Those men who practice terrific austerities not prescribed by the scriptures, given to hypocrisy and egoism, driven by the force of lust and attachment.

Questions: What do people treat Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?

Questions: What do people treat Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?

Questions: What do other warriors treat Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?

Questions: What do the enemies treat Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?

Questions: What do the enemies treat Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?

Questions: What is the crux of Karma Yoga?
Answers: The turbulent senses, O Arjuna, can violently carry away the mind of a wise person, even though they are striving to control them.

Questions: What is the crux of Karma Yoga?
Answers: Abandoning unreservedly all desires born of Sankalpa (thought and imagination) and completely restraining the whole group of senses by the mind from all sides.

Questions: What is the crux of Karma Yoga?
Answers: Mentally renouncing all actions in Me, having Me as the highest goal, and resorting to the yoga of discrimination, do thou ever fix thy mind on Me.

Questions: What is the crux of Karma Yoga?
Answers: Mentally renouncing all actions in Me, having Me as the highest goal, and resorting to the yoga of discrimination, do thou ever fix thy mind on Me.

Questions: What is the crux of Karma Yoga?
Answers: Mentally renouncing all actions and being self-controlled, the embodied one happily rests in the nine-gated city, neither acting nor causing others (body and senses) to act.

Questions: What is the crux of Karma Yoga?
Answers: Serenity of mind, good-heartedness, self-control, and purity of nature—this is called mental austerity.

Questions: What is the crux of Karma Yoga?
Answers: Endowed with a pure intellect, controlling the self through firmness, relinquishing sound and other objects and abandoning attraction and hatred.

Questions: What is the crux of Karma Yoga?
Answers: They say that the senses are superior to the body; the mind is superior to the senses; the intellect is superior to the mind; and He (the Self) is superior even to the intellect.

Questions: What is the crux of Karma Yoga?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "When light, activity, and delusion are present, he does not hate them, nor does he long for them when they are absent.

Questions: What is the crux of Karma Yoga?
Answers: Indifference to the objects of the senses and also absence of egoism; perceiving the evil in birth, death, old age, sickness, and pain.

Questions: What is the crux of Karma Yoga?
Answers: The evil-doers and the deluded, who are the lowest of men, do not seek Me; those whose knowledge is destroyed by illusion follow the ways of demons.

Questions: What is Karma?
Answers: Bewildered by many fancies, entangled in the snare of delusion, addicted to the gratification of lust, they fall into a foul hell.

Questions: What is Karma?

Questions: What is Karma?

Questions: What is Karma?

Questions: What is Karma?

Questions: What is Karma?

Questions: What is Karma?

Questions: What is Karma Yoga?

Questions: What is Karma Yoga?

Questions: What is Karma Yoga?

Questions: What is Karma Yoga?
Answers: They who, by the eye of knowledge, perceive the distinction between the field and its knower, as well as the liberation from the Nature of being, go to the Supreme.

Questions: What is Karma Yoga?
Answers: When your intellect passes beyond the mire of delusion, then you will attain indifference to what has been heard and what has yet to be heard.

Questions: What is Karma Yoga?
Answers: The intellect which knows the path of work and renunciation, what should be done and what should not be done, fear and fearlessness, bondage and liberation—that intellect is Sattvic (pure), O Arjuna.

Questions: What is Karma Yoga?
Answers: But to those whose ignorance is destroyed by knowledge of the Self, like the sun, knowledge reveals the Supreme Brahman.

Questions: What is Karma Yoga?
Answers: The Lord takes neither the demerit nor the merit of any; knowledge is enveloped by ignorance, and beings are deluded.

Questions: What is Karma Yoga?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "O Arjuna, hear how you shall, without doubt, know Me fully, with your mind intent on Me, practicing Yoga and taking refuge in Me."

Questions: What is Karma Yoga?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, I do not see how this Yoga of equanimity, which you have taught me, can be maintained steadily, due to the restlessness of the mind."

Questions: What is Karma Yoga?
Answers: Arjuna said, "He who is unable to control himself, even though he has faith, and whose mind wanders away from Yoga, what end does he meet, having failed to attain perfection in Yoga, O Krishna?"

Questions: How should we work?

Questions: How should we work?

Questions: How should we work?
Answers: But whoever, controlling the senses by the mind, O Arjuna, engages himself in Karma Yoga with the organs of action, without attachment, he excels.

Questions: How should we work?
Answers: O Arjuna, bound by your own Karma (action) born of your own nature, that which from delusion you wish not to do, even that you shall do helplessly.

Questions: How should we work?

Questions: How should we work?

Questions: How should we work?

Questions: How should we work?

Questions: What is the secret of work?

Questions: What is the secret of work?

Questions: What is the secret of Karma?

Questions: What is the secret of Karma?

Questions: What is the secret of Karma?

Questions: What is the definition of Yoga?
Answers: Speaking, letting go, seizing, opening, and closing the eyes, one should be convinced that the senses move among the sense-objects.

Questions: What is the definition of Yoga?
Answers: An eternal portion of Myself having become a living soul in the world of life, draws to itself the five senses, with the mind as the sixth, abiding in Nature.

Questions: What is the definition of Yoga?
Answers: Presiding over the ears, eyes, touch, taste, smell, and mind, it enjoys the objects of the senses.

Questions: What is the definition of Yoga?

Questions: What is the definition of Yoga?
Answers: One sees this (the Self) as a wonder; another speaks of it as a wonder; another hears of it as a wonder; yet, having heard, none understands it at all.

Questions: What is the definition of Yoga?
Answers: Some behold the Self within themselves through meditation, others through the Yoga of knowledge, and still others through the Yoga of action.

Questions: What is the definition of Yoga?

Questions: What is the definition of Yoga?

Questions: What happens to those who have gone beyond the tangle of delusion?
Answers: For the mind, which follows in the wake of the wandering senses, carries away his discrimination, as the wind carries away a boat on the waters.

Questions: What happens to those who have gone beyond the tangle of delusion?

Answers: Thus, always keeping the mind balanced, the yogi, with the mind controlled, attains the peace abiding in Me, culminating in liberation.

Questions: What was Arjuna's first question after hearing about Karma Yoga and the state of equanimity?
Answers: The world is bound by actions other than those performed for the sake of sacrifice; do thou, therefore, O son of Kunti (Arjuna), perform actions for that sake alone, free from attachment.

Questions: What was Arjuna's first question after hearing about Karma Yoga and the state of equanimity?

Questions: Who is considered to be a sthitaprajna?
Answers: In that peace, all pains are destroyed; for the intellect of the tranquil-minded soon becomes steady.

Questions: Who is considered to be a sthitaprajna?

Questions: Who is considered to be equanimous?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "It is desire and it is anger, both of the quality of Rajas, all-devouring and all-sinful; know this as the foe here in this world."

Questions: Who is considered to be equanimous?
Answers: Actions do not taint Me, nor do I have a desire for the fruit of actions. He who knows Me thus is not bound by actions.

Questions: Who is considered to be equanimous?
Answers: Those who constantly practice this teaching of Mine with faith and without caviling, they too are freed from actions.

Questions: Who is considered to be equanimous?

Questions: Who is considered to be equanimous?

Questions: Who is considered to be equanimous?

Questions: Who is considered to be equanimous?
Answers: Attachment and aversion for the objects of the senses abide in the senses; let no one come under their sway; for, they are his enemies.

Questions: Who is considered to be equanimous?

Questions: Who is considered to be equanimous?

Questions: Who is considered to be equanimous?

Questions: Who is considered to be equanimous?

Questions: What is the state of a person who is unbiased?
Answers: Your enemies, scoffing at your power, will speak many abusive words—what could be more painful than this?

Questions: What is the state of a person who is unbiased?
Answers: With this seemingly perplexing speech, you seem to be confusing my understanding; therefore, tell me one certain way by which I may attain bliss.

Questions: What is the state of a person who is unbiased?
Answers: Dwelling in solitude, eating sparingly, with speech, body, and mind subdued, always engaged in meditation and concentration, and resorting to dispassion.

Questions: What is the state of a person who is unbiased?
Answers: Serene-minded, fearless, firm in the vow of a Brahmachari, having controlled their mind, thinking of Me and balanced in mind, let them sit, having Me as their supreme goal.

Questions: What is the state of a person who is unbiased?
Answers: There is no knowledge of the Self for the unsteady, and no meditation is possible for the unsteady, and no peace for the unmeditative, and how can there be happiness for one who has no peace?

Questions: What is the state of a person who is unbiased?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "Renunciation and the Yoga of action both lead to the highest bliss; but of the two, the Yoga of action is superior to the renunciation of action."

Questions: What is the state of a person who is unbiased?
Answers: How shall I, ever meditating, know you, O Yogin? In what aspects or things, O blessed Lord, should I think of you?

Questions: What is the state of a person who is unbiased?
Answers: When the mind, restrained by the practice of yoga, attains quietude, and when one sees the Self by the Self, they are satisfied in their own Self.

Questions: What is the state of a person who is unbiased?
Answers: Perform action, O Arjuna, being steadfast in Yoga, abandoning attachment and balanced in success and failure; evenness of mind is called Yoga.

Answers: Better indeed is knowledge than practice; better than knowledge is meditation; better than meditation is the renunciation of the fruits of actions: peace immediately follows renunciation.

Questions: When is a person's wisdom said to be firmly established?

Questions: What happens to the senses when the Self becomes known?
Answers: The soul seated in Nature experiences the qualities born of Nature; attachment to the qualities is the cause of its birth in good and evil wombs.

Questions: What happens to the senses when the Self becomes known?

Answers: With the self unattached to external contacts, he finds happiness in the Self; with the self engaged in the meditation of Brahman, he attains endless happiness.

Questions: What happens to the senses when the Self becomes known?

Questions: Why do we need to control the senses?

Questions: Why do we need to control the senses?

Questions: What happens when we think about sense objects?

Questions: What happens when we think about sense objects?

Questions: What happens when we think about sense objects?

Questions: What happens when we think about sense objects?
Answers: The sages obtain absolute freedom or Moksha when their sins have been destroyed, their dualities have been torn asunder, they are self-controlled, and they are intent on the welfare of all beings.

Questions: What happens when we think about sense objects?
Answers: All the sages have thus declared Thee, as also the divine sage Narada; so also Asita, Devala, and Vyasa; and now Thou Thyself dost say so to me.

Questions: What happens when we think about sense objects?

Questions: What happens when we think about sense objects?
Answers: And, among the household priests of kings, O Arjuna, know Me to be the chief, Brihaspati; among the army generals, I am Skanda; among lakes, I am the ocean.

Questions: Why is detachment necessary for spiritual progress?
Answers: He who knows Me as the enjoyer of sacrifices and austerities, the great Lord of all the worlds, and the friend of all beings, attains peace.

Questions: Why is detachment necessary for spiritual progress?
Answers: Having seen Thy mouths fearful with teeth blazing like the fires of cosmic dissolution, I know not the four quarters, nor do I find peace. Have mercy, O Lord of the gods, O abode of the universe.

Questions: Why is detachment necessary for spiritual progress?
Answers: In that peace, all pains are destroyed; for the intellect of the tranquil-minded soon becomes steady.

Questions: Why is detachment necessary for spiritual progress?
Answers: Also, the man who hears this, full of faith and free from malice, shall attain to the happy worlds of those of righteous deeds, and be liberated.

Questions: Why is detachment necessary for spiritual progress?
Answers: What is known as the Unmanifested and the Imperishable, That is said to be the highest goal. Those who reach It do not return (to this Samsara). That is My supreme abode (place or state).

Questions: Why is detachment necessary for spiritual progress?
Answers: How much more easily, then, do Brahmins and devoted royal saints attain the goal? Having come to this impermanent and unhappy world, do thou worship Me.

Questions: Why is detachment necessary for spiritual progress?
Answers: That which is declared to be Imperishable by those who know the Vedas, that which the self-controlled (ascetics or Sannyasins) and passion-free enter, that goal, desiring which celibacy is practised, I will declare to thee in brief.

Questions: Why is detachment necessary for spiritual progress?

Questions: What is the effect of work with attachment?

Questions: What is the effect of work with attachment?

Questions: What happens to those who have control over their sense objects?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "Renunciation and the Yoga of action both lead to the highest bliss; but of the two, the Yoga of action is superior to the renunciation of action."

Questions: What happens to those who have control over their sense objects?

Questions: What happens to those who have control over their sense objects?
Answers: Thus, you shall be freed from the bonds of actions yielding good and evil fruits; with the mind steadfast in the Yoga of renunciation, and liberated, you shall come to Me.

Questions: What happens to those who have control over their sense objects?
Answers: Thus, always keeping the mind balanced, the yogi, with the mind controlled, attains the peace abiding in Me, culminating in liberation.

Questions: What happens to those who have control over their sense objects?
Answers: Renouncing all actions in Me, with the mind centered on the Self, free from hope and egoism, and from mental fever, fight thou.

Questions: What happens to those who have control over their sense objects?
Answers: Those who strive for liberation from old age and death, taking refuge in Me, realize in full that Brahman, the whole knowledge of the Self, and all action.

Questions: What happens to those who have control over their sense objects?

Questions: What happens to those who have control over their sense objects?
Answers: Mentally renouncing all actions in Me, having Me as the highest goal, and resorting to the yoga of discrimination, do thou ever fix thy mind on Me.

Questions: What happens to those who have control over their sense objects?

Questions: How can we get over anger?

Questions: How can we become serene?
Answers: When your intellect passes beyond the mire of delusion, then you will attain indifference to what has been heard and what has yet to be heard.

Questions: How can we become serene?
Answers: The evil-doers and the deluded, who are the lowest of men, do not seek Me; those whose knowledge is destroyed by illusion follow the ways of demons.

Questions: How can we become serene?

Questions: How can we become serene?

Questions: How can we become serene?

Questions: How can we become serene?

Answers: You are the Imperishable, the Supreme Being, worthy of being known. You are the great treasure-house of this universe; You are the imperishable protector of the eternal Dharma; You are the Primal Person, I believe.

Questions: How can we become serene?

Questions: How is the state of a serene person?

Questions: How is the state of a serene person?

Questions: How can we attain peace?
Answers: The sages obtain absolute freedom or Moksha when their sins have been destroyed, their dualities have been torn asunder, they are self-controlled, and they are intent on the welfare of all beings.

Questions: How can we attain peace?
Answers: Their intellect absorbed in That, their self being That, established in That, with That as their supreme goal, they go whence there is no return, their sins dispelled by knowledge.

Questions: How can we attain peace?
Answers: But if you will not fight this righteous war, then having abandoned your own duty and reputation, you will incur sin.

Questions: How can we attain peace?
Answers: Having made pleasure and pain, gain and loss, victory and defeat equal, engage in battle for the sake of battle; thus, you shall not incur sin.

Questions: How can we attain peace?
Answers: Without hope, controlling the mind and the self, having abandoned all covetousness, and performing only bodily actions, one incurs no sin.

Questions: How can we attain peace?
Answers: He who does actions, offering them to Brahman and abandoning attachment, is not tainted by sin, just as a lotus leaf is not tainted by water.

Questions: How can we attain peace?
Answers: But those men of virtuous deeds, whose sins have come to an end and who are freed from the delusion of the pairs of opposites, worship Me steadfastly, with their vows.

Questions: How can we attain peace?
Answers: Those men who practice terrific austerities not prescribed by the scriptures, given to hypocrisy and egoism, driven by the force of lust and attachment.

Questions: What is the Brahmic state?

Questions: What is the Brahmic state?
Answers: The foods that increase life, purity, strength, health, joy, and cheerfulness (good appetite), which are savory, oily, substantial, and agreeable, are dear to the Sattvic (pure) people.

Questions: What is the Brahmic state?
Answers: Agriculture, cattle-rearing, and trade are the duties of the Vaisya (merchant), born of their own nature; and service is the duty of the Sudra (servant-class), born of their own nature.

Questions: What is the Brahmic state?

Questions: What is the Brahmic state?
Answers: Having become the fire Vaisvanara, I abide in the bodies of living beings and, associated with the Prana and the Apana, digest the fourfold food.

Questions: What is the Brahmic state?
Answers: Others who regulate their diet offer life-breaths in each life-breath. All these are knowers of sacrifice, whose sins are destroyed through sacrifice.

Questions: What is the Brahmic state?
Answers: Whatever fruit of merit is declared (in the scriptures) to accrue from (the study of) the Vedas, (the performance of) sacrifices, (the practice of) austerities, and gifts, beyond all this goes the Yogi, having known this; and he attains to the Supreme, Primeval (first or ancient) Abode.

Questions: What is the Brahmic state?
Answers: The righteous who eat the remnants of the sacrifice are freed from all sins; but those sinful ones who cook food solely for their own sake indeed consume sin.

Questions: What is the Brahmic state?
Answers: What is action? What is inaction? Even the wise are confused about this. Therefore, I shall teach you the nature of action and inaction, by knowing which you will be liberated from the evil of Samsara, the wheel of birth and death.

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion about knowledge and action?
Answers: From food come forth beings; from rain, food is produced; from sacrifice arises rain, and sacrifice is born of action.

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion about knowledge and action?
Answers: Its branches spread below and above, nourished by the Gunas; its buds are sense-objects, and its roots stretch forth below in the world of men, originating action.

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion about knowledge and action?
Answers: It is within and without all beings, both the unmoving and the moving; It is subtle and unknowable, and It is near and far away.

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion about knowledge and action?
Answers: For a sage who wishes to attain to Yoga, action is said to be the means; for the same sage who has attained Yoga, inaction is said to be the means.

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion about knowledge and action?
Answers: Presiding over the ears, eyes, touch, taste, smell, and mind, it enjoys the objects of the senses.

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion about knowledge and action?
Answers: The threefold fruit of action (evil, good, and mixed) accrues after death to those who do not abandon it, but never to those who do.

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion about knowledge and action?
Answers: Neither does the Lord create agency nor actions for the world, nor union with the fruits of actions; rather, it is Nature that acts.

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion about knowledge and action?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "Renunciation and the Yoga of action both lead to the highest bliss; but of the two, the Yoga of action is superior to the renunciation of action."

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion about knowledge and action?
Answers: Verily, no one can remain for even a moment without performing action; for everyone is made to act helplessly, indeed, by the qualities born of Nature.

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion about knowledge and action?
Answers: Even a wise man acts in accordance with his own nature; beings will follow their nature; what can restraint do?

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion about knowledge and action?
Answers: Know that Nature (matter) and the Spirit are both beginningless, and know also that all modifications and qualities are born from Nature.

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion on hearing about the Yoga of knowledge and the Yoga of action?
Answers: Verily, no one can remain for even a moment without performing action; for everyone is made to act helplessly, indeed, by the qualities born of Nature.

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion on hearing about the Yoga of knowledge and the Yoga of action?
Answers: In the production of the effect and the cause, Nature (matter) is said to be the cause; in the experience of pleasure and pain, the soul is said to be the one responsible.

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion on hearing about the Yoga of knowledge and the Yoga of action?
Answers: For verily, the true nature of action enjoined by the scriptures should be known, as well as that of forbidden or unlawful action, and of inaction; the nature of action is hard to understand.

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion on hearing about the Yoga of knowledge and the Yoga of action?
Answers: Those deluded by the qualities of Nature are attached to the functions of the qualities. The man of perfect knowledge should not unsettle the foolish one who is of imperfect knowledge.

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion on hearing about the Yoga of knowledge and the Yoga of action?
Answers: Deluded by these Natures, composed of the three qualities of Nature, all this world does not know Me as distinct from them and immutable.

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion on hearing about the Yoga of knowledge and the Yoga of action?
Answers: Neither does the Lord create agency nor actions for the world, nor union with the fruits of actions; rather, it is Nature that acts.

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion on hearing about the Yoga of knowledge and the Yoga of action?
Answers: All actions are wrought in all cases by the qualities of Nature alone. He whose mind is deluded by egoism thinks, "I am the doer."

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion on hearing about the Yoga of knowledge and the Yoga of action?
Answers: Earth, water, fire, air, ether, mind, intellect, and egoism—thus is My Nature divided eightfold.

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion on hearing about the Yoga of knowledge and the Yoga of action?
Answers: Each person devoted to their own duty attains perfection. How they attain perfection while being engaged in their own duty, hear now.

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion on hearing about the Yoga of knowledge and the Yoga of action?
Answers: Serenity, self-restraint, austerity, purity, forgiveness, and uprightness, as well as knowledge, realization, and belief in God, are the duties of Brahmanas, born of their own nature.

Questions: What was Arjuna's confusion on hearing about the Yoga of knowledge and the Yoga of action?
Answers: Better is one's own duty, even if it is destitute of merits, than the duty of another well performed. He who does the duty ordained by his own nature incurs no sin.

Questions: Is there any mention of Sankhya Yoga in the Gita?
Answers: But for that man who rejoices only in the Self, who is satisfied with the Self and is content in the Self alone, indeed there is nothing to do.

Questions: Is there any mention of Sankhya Yoga in the Gita?
Answers: When the mind, restrained by the practice of yoga, attains quietude, and when one sees the Self by the Self, they are satisfied in their own Self.

Questions: Is there any mention of Sankhya Yoga in the Gita?

Questions: Is there any mention of Sankhya Yoga in the Gita?
Answers: Non-attachment, non-identification of the Self with son, wife, home, and the rest, and constant even-mindedness in the face of the attainment of both desirable and undesirable.

Questions: Does renunciation of work lead to liberation or salvation?

Questions: Does renunciation of work lead to liberation or salvation?

Questions: Does renunciation of work lead to liberation or salvation?
Answers: That person attains peace who, abandoning all desires, moves about without longing, without the sense of ownership, and without egoism.

Questions: Does renunciation of work lead to liberation or salvation?

Questions: Does renunciation of work lead to liberation or salvation?

Questions: Does renunciation of work lead to liberation or salvation?

Questions: Does renunciation of work lead to liberation or salvation?

Questions: Does renunciation of work lead to liberation or salvation?

Questions: Can any person avoid doing action or work even for a moment?

Questions: Can any person avoid doing action or work even for a moment?

Questions: Who is a deluded person?

Questions: Who is an excellent person?

Questions: Who is an excellent person?

Questions: Who is an excellent person?

Questions: Who is an excellent person?

Answers: Its branches spread below and above, nourished by the Gunas; its buds are sense-objects, and its roots stretch forth below in the world of men, originating action.

Questions: How can pious people remain free from sin?
Answers: When the seer beholds no agent other than the Gunas and knows that which is higher than them, he attains to My Being.

Questions: How can pious people remain free from sin?
Answers: To one who is devoid of attachment, who is liberated, whose mind is established in knowledge, and who works for the sake of sacrifice (for the sake of God), the whole action is dissolved.

Questions: How can pious people remain free from sin?
Answers: Weapons cannot cut it, fire cannot burn it, water cannot wet it, wind cannot dry it.

Questions: How can pious people remain free from sin?
Answers: The embodied one, having crossed beyond these three Gunas from which the body is evolved, is freed from birth, death, decay, and pain, and attains immortality.

Questions: How can pious people remain free from sin?
Answers: Therefore, O mighty-armed Arjuna, his knowledge is steady whose senses are completely restrained from sense objects.

Questions: How can pious people remain free from sin?
Answers: Hear thou the threefold division of intellect and firmness, according to the Gunas, as I declare them fully and distinctly, O Arjuna.

Questions: How can pious people remain free from sin?
Answers: Let no wise man unsettle the minds of ignorant people who are attached to action; he should engage them in all actions, himself fulfilling them with devotion.

Questions: How can pious people remain free from sin?
Answers: Out of mere compassion for them, I, dwelling within their selves, destroy the darkness born of ignorance with the luminous lamp of knowledge.

Questions: How can pious people remain free from sin?
Answers: As the ignorant act out of attachment to action, O Bharata, so should the wise act without attachment, wishing for the welfare of the world.

Questions: How can pious people remain free from sin?
Answers: But those who criticize My teaching and do not practice it, deprived of all knowledge and lacking discernment, know them to be doomed to destruction.

Questions: How can pious people remain free from sin?
Answers: The Lord takes neither the demerit nor the merit of any; knowledge is enveloped by ignorance, and beings are deluded.

Questions: What is the importance of food?
Answers: Constancy in Self-knowledge, the perception of the end of true knowledge—this is declared to be knowledge, and what is opposed to it is ignorance.

Questions: What is the importance of food?
Answers: But know thou Tamas to be born of ignorance, deluding all embodied beings; it binds fast, O Arjuna, through heedlessness, indolence, and sleep.

Questions: What is the importance of food?
Answers: They who, by the eye of knowledge, perceive the distinction between the field and its knower, as well as the liberation from the Nature of being, go to the Supreme.

Questions: What is the importance of food?
Answers: Whosoever meditates on the Omniscient, the Ancient, the Ruler of the whole world, minuter than an atom, the supporter of all, of inconceivable form, effulgent like the sun and beyond the darkness of ignorance.

Questions: What is the importance of food?
Answers: But to those whose ignorance is destroyed by knowledge of the Self, like the sun, knowledge reveals the Supreme Brahman.

Questions: What is the importance of food?

Questions: What is the importance of food?

Questions: What is the importance of food?

Questions: What is the importance of food?
Answers: Arjuna said, "Having seen this Thy gentle human form, O Krishna, now I am composed and have been restored to my own nature."

Questions: What is the importance of food?
Answers: To him who was despondent in the midst of the two armies, Krishna, smiling, O Bharata, spoke these words.

Questions: What is the importance of food?
Answers: Arjuna said, "It is fitting, O Krishna, that the world delights and rejoices in Your praise; demons fly in fear in all directions and the hosts of the perfected ones bow to You."

Questions: Where does activity or action spring from?
Answers: Sanjaya said, Having heard that speech of Lord Krishna, Arjuna, with joined palms, trembling, prostrated himself, again addressing Krishna in a choked voice, bowing down, overwhelmed with fear.

Questions: Where does activity or action spring from?
Answers: Arjuna said: If Thou thinkest that knowledge is superior to action, O Krishna, why then, O Kesava, doest Thou ask me to engage in this terrible action?

Questions: Where does activity or action spring from?
Answers: Tell me again in detail, O Krishna, of your yogic power and glory; for I am not satiated with what I have heard of your life-giving and nectar-like speech.

Questions: Where does activity or action spring from?
Answers: Sanjaya said: Having spoken thus to Hrishikesha, the Lord of the senses, Arjuna, the conqueror of sleep and destroyer of foes, said, "I will not fight," and became silent.

Questions: Where does activity or action spring from?
Answers: Arjuna said, "What is the condition of those who, disregarding the injunctions of the scriptures, perform sacrifice with faith—is it Sattva, Rajas, or Tamas, O Krishna?"

Questions: Where does activity or action spring from?
Answers: The faith of each is in accordance with their nature, O Arjuna. People consist of their faith; as a person's faith is, so are they.

Questions: Where does activity or action spring from?
Answers: The faith of each is in accordance with their nature, O Arjuna. People consist of their faith; as a person's faith is, so are they.

Questions: Where does activity or action spring from?

Questions: Where does activity or action spring from?
Answers: Arjuna said, "He who is unable to control himself, even though he has faith, and whose mind wanders away from Yoga, what end does he meet, having failed to attain perfection in Yoga, O Krishna?"

Questions: Where does activity or action spring from?
Answers: Arjuna said, "It is fitting, O Krishna, that the world delights and rejoices in Your praise; demons fly in fear in all directions and the hosts of the perfected ones bow to You."

Questions: Where does activity or action spring from?
Answers: Arjuna said, "My delusion has been destroyed, for I have gained my knowledge (memory) through Your grace, O Krishna. I am now free from doubts. I will act according to Your word."

Questions: Why is it important to follow the laws of nature?
Answers: When a person is not attached to the sense-objects or to actions, having renounced all thoughts, then they are said to have attained Yoga.

Questions: Why is it important to follow the laws of nature?
Answers: Endowed with wisdom and evenness of mind, one casts off in this life both good and evil deeds; therefore, devote yourself to Yoga; Yoga is skill in action.

Questions: Why is it important to follow the laws of nature?
Answers: Endowed with wisdom and evenness of mind, one casts off in this life both good and evil deeds; therefore, devote yourself to Yoga; Yoga is skill in action.

Questions: Why is it important to follow the laws of nature?
Answers: But whoever, controlling the senses by the mind, O Arjuna, engages himself in Karma Yoga with the organs of action, without attachment, he excels.

Questions: Why is it important to follow the laws of nature?
Answers: Do you, O Arjuna, know that Yoga is what they call renunciation; no one indeed becomes a Yogi who has not renounced their thoughts.

Questions: Why is it important to follow the laws of nature?
Answers: By that same former practice, he is borne on in spite of himself. Even he who merely wishes to know Yoga goes beyond the Brahmanic word.

Questions: Why is it important to follow the laws of nature?
Answers: He who has renounced actions through Yoga, whose doubts have been dispelled by knowledge, and who is self-possessed—such a one is not bound by actions, O Arjuna.

Questions: Why is it important to follow the laws of nature?
Answers: Perform action, O Arjuna, being steadfast in Yoga, abandoning attachment and balanced in success and failure; evenness of mind is called Yoga.

Questions: Do people who are satisfied with the Self also need to perform all the worldly duties?
Answers: Perform action, O Arjuna, being steadfast in Yoga, abandoning attachment and balanced in success and failure; evenness of mind is called Yoga.

Questions: Do people who are satisfied with the Self also need to perform all the worldly duties?
Answers: I think Yoga is hard to be attained by one with an uncontrolled self, but the self-controlled and striving one can attain it by the appropriate means.

Questions: Do people who are satisfied with the Self also need to perform all the worldly duties?
Answers: Giving themselves over to immeasurable cares that end only with death, regarding the gratification of lust as their highest aim, and feeling sure that that is all.

Questions: Do people who are satisfied with the Self also need to perform all the worldly duties?
Answers: An action that is ordained, free from attachment, done without love or hatred, and without desire for reward is declared to be Sattvic.

Questions: Do people who are satisfied with the Self also need to perform all the worldly duties?
Answers: When one thinks of objects, attachment to them arises; from attachment, desire is born; from desire, anger arises.

Questions: Do people who are satisfied with the Self also need to perform all the worldly duties?
Answers: Abandoning unreservedly all desires born of Sankalpa (thought and imagination) and completely restraining the whole group of senses by the mind from all sides.

Questions: Do people who are satisfied with the Self also need to perform all the worldly duties?
Answers: Filled with insatiable desires, full of hypocrisy, pride, and arrogance, holding evil ideas due to delusion, they work with impure intentions.

Questions: Is there any motivation left for people who are satisfied with the Self?
Answers: That which is like poison at first but in the end like nectar—that happiness is declared to be sattvic, born of the purity of one's own mind due to self-realization.

Questions: Is there any motivation left for people who are satisfied with the Self?
Answers: Speaking, letting go, seizing, opening, and closing the eyes, one should be convinced that the senses move among the sense-objects.

Questions: Is there any motivation left for people who are satisfied with the Self?
Answers: Presiding over the ears, eyes, touch, taste, smell, and mind, it enjoys the objects of the senses.

Questions: Is there any motivation left for people who are satisfied with the Self?
Answers: The senses, the mind, and the intellect are said to be its seat; through these, it deludes the embodied one, veiling their wisdom.

Questions: Is there any motivation left for people who are satisfied with the Self?
Answers: Indifference to the objects of the senses and also absence of egoism; perceiving the evil in birth, death, old age, sickness, and pain.

Questions: Is there any motivation left for people who are satisfied with the Self?
Answers: They say that the senses are superior to the body; the mind is superior to the senses; the intellect is superior to the mind; and He (the Self) is superior even to the intellect.

Questions: Is there any motivation left for people who are satisfied with the Self?
Answers: He sees, who sees that all actions are performed solely by Nature and that the Self is without action.

Questions: Is there any motivation left for people who are satisfied with the Self?
Answers: Therefore, O best of the Bharatas, control your senses first and then kill this sinful thing, which destroys knowledge and realization.

Questions: Is there any motivation left for people who are satisfied with the Self?
Answers: The turbulent senses, O Arjuna, can violently carry away the mind of a wise person, even though they are striving to control them.

Questions: Is there any motivation left for people who are satisfied with the Self?
Answers: Others again sacrifice all the functions of the senses and those of the breath (vital energy, or Prana) in the fire of the Yoga of self-restraint, kindled by knowledge.

Questions: Is there any motivation left for people who are satisfied with the Self?
Answers: There, having made the mind one-pointed, with the actions of the mind and senses controlled, let him, seated on the seat, practice Yoga for the purification of the self.

Questions: Why is detachment important?
Answers: Better is one's own duty, even if it is destitute of merits, than the duty of another well performed. He who does the duty ordained by his own nature incurs no sin.

Questions: Why is detachment important?
Answers: Better is one's own duty, even if it is destitute of merits, than the duty of another well performed. He who does the duty ordained by his own nature incurs no sin.

Questions: Why is detachment important?
Answers: Of Brahmanas, Kshatriyas, Vaisyas, and Sudras, O Arjuna, the duties are distributed according to the qualities born of their own nature.

Questions: Why is detachment important?
Answers: Better is one's own duty, though devoid of merit, than the duty of another well discharged. Better is death in one's own duty; the duty of another is fraught with fear.

Questions: Why is detachment important?
Answers: Perform your bounden duty, for action is superior to inaction, and even the maintenance of the body would not be possible for you through inaction.

Questions: What is the result of detachment?

Questions: What is the result of detachment?

Questions: What is the result of detachment?

Questions: What is the result of detachment?
Answers: With this, nourish the gods, and may the gods nourish you; thus, nourishing each other, you shall attain the highest good.

Questions: What is the result of detachment?
Answers: Having closed all the gates, confined the mind in the heart, and fixed the life-breath in the head, engage in the practice of concentration.

Questions: How should wise men treat other human beings?
Answers: Bewildered by many fancies, entangled in the snare of delusion, addicted to the gratification of lust, they fall into a foul hell.

Questions: How should wise men treat other human beings?
Answers: Giving themselves over to immeasurable cares that end only with death, regarding the gratification of lust as their highest aim, and feeling sure that that is all.

Questions: How should wise men treat other human beings?
Answers: The enjoyments that arise from contact are only sources of pain, for they have a beginning and an end, O Arjuna; the wise do not rejoice in them.

Questions: How should wise men treat other human beings?
Answers: But that action which is done by one longing for the fulfillment of desires or gain with egotism or with much effort is declared to be Rajasic (passionate).

Questions: How should wise men treat other human beings?
Answers: Bound by a hundred ties of hope, given over to lust and anger, they strive to obtain hoards of wealth by unlawful means for sensual enjoyment.

Questions: How should wise men treat other human beings?
Answers: Full of desires, with heaven as their goal, (they speak words that are directed to ends) leading to new births as the result of their works, and prescribe various methods abounding in specific actions, for the attainment of pleasure and power.

Questions: How should wise men treat other human beings?
Answers: Of the strong, I am the strength devoid of desire and attachment, and in all beings, I am the desire in accordance with Dharma, O Arjuna.

Questions: How should wise men treat other human beings?
Answers: Desire, hatred, pleasure, pain, the aggregate (body), intelligence, and fortitude—the field has thus been briefly described with its modifications.

Questions: How should wise men treat other human beings?
Answers: He attains peace into whom all desires enter, just as waters enter the ocean which, filled from all sides, remains unmoved; but not the man who is full of desires.

Questions: How should wise men treat other human beings?
Answers: Non-attachment, non-identification of the Self with son, wife, home, and the rest, and constant even-mindedness in the face of the attainment of both desirable and undesirable.

Questions: How should the ignorant be treated?
Answers: The intellect which knows the path of work and renunciation, what should be done and what should not be done, fear and fearlessness, bondage and liberation—that intellect is Sattvic (pure), O Arjuna.

Questions: How should the ignorant be treated?
Answers: When your intellect, which is perplexed by the Vedic texts you have read, stands immovable and steady in the Self, then you will attain Self-realization.

Questions: How should the ignorant be treated?
Answers: The senses, the mind, and the intellect are said to be its seat; through these, it deludes the embodied one, veiling their wisdom.

Questions: How should the ignorant be treated?
Answers: Little by little, let him attain steadiness of the intellect by holding it firmly; having made the mind establish itself in the Self, let him not think of anything else.

Questions: How should the ignorant be treated?
Answers: Some behold the Self within themselves through meditation, others through the Yoga of knowledge, and still others through the Yoga of action.

Questions: How should the ignorant be treated?

Questions: What are the kinds of oblations that Yogis perform?
Answers: Having abandoned attachment to the fruits of the action, ever content, depending on nothing, he does not do anything even while being engaged in activity.

Questions: What are the kinds of oblations that Yogis perform?
Answers: Verily, no one can remain for even a moment without performing action; for everyone is made to act helplessly, indeed, by the qualities born of Nature.

Questions: What are the kinds of oblations that Yogis perform?
Answers: Your right is only to work, but not to its results; do not let the results of action be your motive, nor let your attachment be to inaction.

Questions: What are the kinds of oblations that Yogis perform?
Answers: Your right is only to work, but not to its results; do not let the results of action be your motive, nor let your attachment be to inaction.

Questions: What are the kinds of oblations that Yogis perform?
Answers: What is action? What is inaction? Even the wise are confused about this. Therefore, I shall teach you the nature of action and inaction, by knowing which you will be liberated from the evil of Samsara, the wheel of birth and death.

Questions: What are the kinds of oblations that Yogis perform?
Answers: Perform your bounden duty, for action is superior to inaction, and even the maintenance of the body would not be possible for you through inaction.

Questions: What are the kinds of oblations that Yogis perform?

Questions: What are the kinds of oblations that Yogis perform?
