Questions: How does it help to have the knowledge of kshetra and kshetrajna?
Answers: How much more easily, then, do Brahmins and devoted royal saints attain the goal? Having come to this impermanent and unhappy world, do thou worship Me.

Questions: How does it help to have the knowledge of kshetra and kshetrajna?
Answers: They, having enjoyed the vast heaven, enter the world of mortals when their merit is exhausted; thus abiding by the injunctions of the three (Vedas) and desiring objects of desires, they attain to the state of coming and going.

Questions: How does it help to have the knowledge of kshetra and kshetrajna?
Answers: Without hope, controlling the mind and the self, having abandoned all covetousness, and performing only bodily actions, one incurs no sin.

Questions: How does it help to have the knowledge of kshetra and kshetrajna?
Answers:
I desire not victory, O Krishna, nor kingdom, nor pleasures.
What use is dominion to us, O Krishna, or pleasures or even life?

Questions: How does it help to have the knowledge of kshetra and kshetrajna?
Answers: For he who truly sees the same Lord dwelling everywhere does not destroy the Self by the self; rather, he attains the highest goal.

Questions: How does it help to have the knowledge of kshetra and kshetrajna?
Answers: That person attains peace who, abandoning all desires, moves about without longing, without the sense of ownership, and without egoism.

Questions: How does it help to have the knowledge of kshetra and kshetrajna?
Answers: Abandoning unreservedly all desires born of Sankalpa (thought and imagination) and completely restraining the whole group of senses by the mind from all sides.

Questions: How does it help to have the knowledge of kshetra and kshetrajna?
Answers: He attains peace into whom all desires enter, just as waters enter the ocean which, filled from all sides, remains unmoved; but not the man who is full of desires.

Questions: How does it help to have the knowledge of kshetra and kshetrajna?
Answers: O Krishna, please completely dispel this doubt of mine, for it is not possible for anyone but You to do so.

Questions: How does it help to have the knowledge of kshetra and kshetrajna?
Answers: Absolute freedom exists on all sides for those self-controlled ascetics who are free from desire and anger, who have controlled their thoughts, and who have realized the Self.

Questions: How does it help to have the knowledge of kshetra and kshetrajna?
Answers: Free from pride and delusion, victorious over the evil of attachment, dwelling constantly in the Self, their desires having completely turned away, freed from the pairs of opposites known as pleasure and pain, they, the undeluded, reach the eternal goal.

Questions: Who is fit to attain salvation?
Answers: I am easily attainable by that ever-steadfast yogi who constantly and daily remembers me for a long time, not thinking of anything else with a single-minded or one-pointed focus, O Partha.

Questions: Who is fit to attain salvation?
Answers: But that action which is done by one longing for the fulfillment of desires or gain with egotism or with much effort is declared to be Rajasic (passionate).

Questions: Who is fit to attain salvation?
Answers: An action that is ordained, free from attachment, done without love or hatred, and without desire for reward is declared to be Sattvic.

Questions: Who is fit to attain salvation?
Answers: Of the strong, I am the strength devoid of desire and attachment, and in all beings, I am the desire in accordance with Dharma, O Arjuna.

Questions: Who is fit to attain salvation?
Answers: The embodied one, having crossed beyond these three Gunas from which the body is evolved, is freed from birth, death, decay, and pain, and attains immortality.

Questions: Who is fit to attain salvation?
Answers: There is no being on earth or in heaven among the gods that is liberated from the three qualities born of Nature.

Questions: Who is fit to attain salvation?
Answers: Absolute freedom exists on all sides for those self-controlled ascetics who are free from desire and anger, who have controlled their thoughts, and who have realized the Self.

Questions: Who is fit to attain salvation?
Answers: O Krishna, please completely dispel this doubt of mine, for it is not possible for anyone but You to do so.

Questions: Who is fit to attain salvation?
Answers: He who, seated like one unconcerned, is not moved by the dualities, and who, knowing that the dualities are active, is self-centered and does not move.

Questions: Who is fit to attain salvation?
Answers: Those who, having taken refuge in this knowledge, have attained unity with Me, are neither born at the time of creation nor disturbed at the time of dissolution.

Questions: Who is fit to attain salvation?
Answers: Nor do beings exist in Me (in reality); behold, My divine Yoga, which supports all beings, but does not dwell in them, is My Self, the efficient cause of beings.

Questions: When did Prakriti and Purusha originate?
Answers: Know that these two are the womb of all beings; thus, I am the source and dissolution of the whole universe.

Questions: When did Prakriti and Purusha originate?
Answers: Abandoning unreservedly all desires born of Sankalpa (thought and imagination) and completely restraining the whole group of senses by the mind from all sides.

Questions: When did Prakriti and Purusha originate?
Answers: The sages obtain absolute freedom or Moksha when their sins have been destroyed, their dualities have been torn asunder, they are self-controlled, and they are intent on the welfare of all beings.

Questions: When did Prakriti and Purusha originate?
Answers: They who, by the eye of knowledge, perceive the distinction between the field and its knower, as well as the liberation from the Nature of being, go to the Supreme.

Questions: When did Prakriti and Purusha originate?
Answers: Those whose wisdom has been taken away by this or that desire, go to other gods, following this or that rite, led by their own nature.

Questions: When did Prakriti and Purusha originate?
Answers: He who sees the Supreme Lord existing truly in all beings, the imperishable within the perishable, sees indeed.

Questions: When did Prakriti and Purusha originate?
Answers: They, having enjoyed the vast heaven, enter the world of mortals when their merit is exhausted; thus abiding by the injunctions of the three (Vedas) and desiring objects of desires, they attain to the state of coming and going.

Questions: When did Prakriti and Purusha originate?
Answers: And why should they not, O great Soul, bow to Thee Who art greater than all else, the primal cause even of the Creator (Brahma), O Infinite Being, O Lord of the gods, O Abode of the universe; Thou art the imperishable, the Being, the non-being, and That which is supreme—that which is beyond the Being and the non-being.

Questions: When did Prakriti and Purusha originate?
Answers: The worshippers of the gods go to them; the ancestor-worshippers go to the manes; the worshippers of the deities who preside over the elements go to them; but My devotees come to Me.

Questions: When did Prakriti and Purusha originate?
Answers: Those who worship the imperishable, the indefinable, the unmanifest, the omnipresent, the unthinkable, the immovable, and the eternal.

Questions: When did Prakriti and Purusha originate?
Answers: Others, too, who do not know thus, worship, having heard of It from others; they, too, cross beyond death, regarding what they have heard as the supreme refuge.

Questions: What is the role of the Self or Purusha in human experience?
Answers: Their intellect absorbed in That, their self being That, established in That, with That as their supreme goal, they go whence there is no return, their sins dispelled by knowledge.

Questions: What is the role of the Self or Purusha in human experience?
Answers: What is known as the Unmanifested and the Imperishable, That is said to be the highest goal. Those who reach It do not return (to this Samsara). That is My supreme abode (place or state).

Questions: What is the role of the Self or Purusha in human experience?
Answers: Presiding over the ears, eyes, touch, taste, smell, and mind, it enjoys the objects of the senses.

Questions: What is the role of the Self or Purusha in human experience?
Answers: When one thinks of objects, attachment to them arises; from attachment, desire is born; from desire, anger arises.

Questions: What is the role of the Self or Purusha in human experience?
Answers: When one thinks of objects, attachment to them arises; from attachment, desire is born; from desire, anger arises.

Questions: What is the role of the Self or Purusha in human experience?
Answers: When one thinks of objects, attachment to them arises; from attachment, desire is born; from desire, anger arises.

Questions: What is the role of the Self or Purusha in human experience?
Answers: When one thinks of objects, attachment to them arises; from attachment, desire is born; from desire, anger arises.

Questions: What is the role of the Self or Purusha in human experience?
Answers: The objects of the senses turn away from the abstinent man, leaving the longing behind; but his longing also turns away upon seeing the Supreme.

Questions: What is the role of the Self or Purusha in human experience?
Answers: Giving themselves over to immeasurable cares that end only with death, regarding the gratification of lust as their highest aim, and feeling sure that that is all.

Questions: What is the role of the Self or Purusha in human experience?
Answers: Attachment and aversion for the objects of the senses abide in the senses; let no one come under their sway; for, they are his enemies.

Questions: What is the role of the Self or Purusha in human experience?
Answers: The enjoyments that arise from contact are only sources of pain, for they have a beginning and an end, O Arjuna; the wise do not rejoice in them.

Questions: Who experiences the nature around perceived through the sense organs?
Answers: Desire, hatred, pleasure, pain, the aggregate (body), intelligence, and fortitude—the field has thus been briefly described with its modifications.

Questions: Who experiences the nature around perceived through the sense organs?
Answers: And whoever, leaving their body, goes forth remembering Me alone at the time of death, they will attain My Being; there is no doubt about this.

Questions: Who experiences the nature around perceived through the sense organs?
Answers: Just as the embodied soul passes through childhood, youth, and old age in this body, so too does it pass into another body; the steadfast one does not grieve over this.

Questions: Who experiences the nature around perceived through the sense organs?
Answers: Just as the embodied soul passes through childhood, youth, and old age in this body, so too does it pass into another body; the steadfast one does not grieve over this.

Questions: Who experiences the nature around perceived through the sense organs?
Answers: Just as the embodied soul passes through childhood, youth, and old age in this body, so too does it pass into another body; the steadfast one does not grieve over this.

Questions: Who experiences the nature around perceived through the sense organs?
Answers: An eternal portion of Myself having become a living soul in the world of life, draws to itself the five senses, with the mind as the sixth, abiding in Nature.

Questions: Who experiences the nature around perceived through the sense organs?
Answers: Whoever at the end leaves the body, thinking of any being, to that being only does he go, O son of Kunti (Arjuna), due to his constant thought of that being.

Questions: Who experiences the nature around perceived through the sense organs?
Answers: The Supreme Soul in this body is also called the observer, the permitter, the sustainer, the enjoyer, the great Lord, and the Supreme Self.

Questions: Who experiences the nature around perceived through the sense organs?
Answers: Some behold the Self within themselves through meditation, others through the Yoga of knowledge, and still others through the Yoga of action.

Questions: Who experiences the nature around perceived through the sense organs?
Answers: At the time of death, with an unwavering mind, endowed with devotion, by the power of Yoga, fixing the whole life-breath in the middle of the two eyebrows, he reaches that resplendent Supreme Person.

Questions: Who experiences the nature around perceived through the sense organs?
Answers: He who thus knows the Spirit and Matter together with their qualities, in whatever condition he may be, he is not reborn.

Questions: What is the role of the Self or seer in the human body?
Answers: They say that the senses are superior to the body; the mind is superior to the senses; the intellect is superior to the mind; and He (the Self) is superior even to the intellect.

Questions: What is the role of the Self or seer in the human body?
Answers: An eternal portion of Myself having become a living soul in the world of life, draws to itself the five senses, with the mind as the sixth, abiding in Nature.

Questions: What is the role of the Self or seer in the human body?
Answers: Speaking, letting go, seizing, opening, and closing the eyes, one should be convinced that the senses move among the sense-objects.

Questions: What is the role of the Self or seer in the human body?
Answers: The senses, the mind, and the intellect are said to be its seat; through these, it deludes the embodied one, veiling their wisdom.

Questions: What is the role of the Self or seer in the human body?
Answers: With the mind harmonized by Yoga, he sees the Self abiding in all beings and all beings in the Self; he sees the same everywhere.

Questions: What is the role of the Self or seer in the human body?
Answers: Some behold the Self within themselves through meditation, others through the Yoga of knowledge, and still others through the Yoga of action.

Questions: What is the role of the Self or seer in the human body?
Answers: Some again offer the organ of hearing and other senses as a sacrifice in the fire of restraint; others offer sound and other objects of the senses as a sacrifice in the fire of the senses.

Questions: What is the role of the Self or seer in the human body?
Answers: The great elements, egoism, intellect, and also the Unmanifested Nature, the ten senses, and one mind, and the five objects of the senses.

Questions: What is the role of the Self or seer in the human body?
Answers: Indifference to the objects of the senses and also absence of egoism; perceiving the evil in birth, death, old age, sickness, and pain.

Questions: What is the role of the Self or seer in the human body?
Answers: The Supreme Soul in this body is also called the observer, the permitter, the sustainer, the enjoyer, the great Lord, and the Supreme Self.

Questions: What is the role of the Self or seer in the human body?
Answers: With the mind harmonized by Yoga, he sees the Self abiding in all beings and all beings in the Self; he sees the same everywhere.

Questions: What is the benefit of gaining knowledge of Purusha and Prakriti?
Answers: Some behold the Self within themselves through meditation, others through the Yoga of knowledge, and still others through the Yoga of action.

Questions: What is the benefit of gaining knowledge of Purusha and Prakriti?
Answers: An eternal portion of Myself having become a living soul in the world of life, draws to itself the five senses, with the mind as the sixth, abiding in Nature.

Questions: What is the benefit of gaining knowledge of Purusha and Prakriti?
Answers: The senses, the mind, and the intellect are said to be its seat; through these, it deludes the embodied one, veiling their wisdom.

Questions: What is the benefit of gaining knowledge of Purusha and Prakriti?
Answers: They say that the senses are superior to the body; the mind is superior to the senses; the intellect is superior to the mind; and He (the Self) is superior even to the intellect.

Questions: What is the benefit of gaining knowledge of Purusha and Prakriti?
Answers: He sees, who sees that all actions are performed solely by Nature and that the Self is without action.

Questions: What is the benefit of gaining knowledge of Purusha and Prakriti?
Answers: When a person sees all beings as resting in the One and emanating from the One alone, they then become Brahman.

Questions: What is the benefit of gaining knowledge of Purusha and Prakriti?
Answers: One sees this (the Self) as a wonder; another speaks of it as a wonder; another hears of it as a wonder; yet, having heard, none understands it at all.

Questions: What is the benefit of gaining knowledge of Purusha and Prakriti?
Answers: Nor do beings exist in Me (in reality); behold, My divine Yoga, which supports all beings, but does not dwell in them, is My Self, the efficient cause of beings.

Questions: What is the benefit of gaining knowledge of Purusha and Prakriti?
Answers: All of this world is pervaded by Me in My unmanifest aspect; all beings exist within Me, but I do not dwell within them.

Questions: What is the benefit of gaining knowledge of Purusha and Prakriti?
Answers: With the mind harmonized by Yoga, he sees the Self abiding in all beings and all beings in the Self; he sees the same everywhere.

Questions: What is the benefit of gaining knowledge of Purusha and Prakriti?
Answers: An eternal portion of Myself having become a living soul in the world of life, draws to itself the five senses, with the mind as the sixth, abiding in Nature.

Questions: What are the various ways of realising or perceiving the self within the body?
Answers: Some behold the Self within themselves through meditation, others through the Yoga of knowledge, and still others through the Yoga of action.

Questions: What are the various ways of realising or perceiving the self within the body?
Answers: The senses, the mind, and the intellect are said to be its seat; through these, it deludes the embodied one, veiling their wisdom.

Questions: What are the various ways of realising or perceiving the self within the body?
Answers: One sees this (the Self) as a wonder; another speaks of it as a wonder; another hears of it as a wonder; yet, having heard, none understands it at all.

Questions: What are the various ways of realising or perceiving the self within the body?
Answers: He sees, who sees that all actions are performed solely by Nature and that the Self is without action.

Questions: What are the various ways of realising or perceiving the self within the body?
Answers: They say that the senses are superior to the body; the mind is superior to the senses; the intellect is superior to the mind; and He (the Self) is superior even to the intellect.

Questions: What are the various ways of realising or perceiving the self within the body?
Answers: Nor do beings exist in Me (in reality); behold, My divine Yoga, which supports all beings, but does not dwell in them, is My Self, the efficient cause of beings.

Questions: What are the various ways of realising or perceiving the self within the body?
Answers: When your intellect, which is perplexed by the Vedic texts you have read, stands immovable and steady in the Self, then you will attain Self-realization.

Questions: What are the various ways of realising or perceiving the self within the body?
Answers: Just as the embodied soul passes through childhood, youth, and old age in this body, so too does it pass into another body; the steadfast one does not grieve over this.

Questions: What are the various ways of realising or perceiving the self within the body?
Answers: That Light of all lights is said to be beyond darkness: knowledge, the knowable, and the goal of knowledge, seated in the hearts of all.

Questions: What are the various ways of realising or perceiving the self within the body?
Answers: Neither does the sun illuminate there, nor the moon, nor the fire; having gone there, they do not return; that is My supreme abode.

Questions: What are the various ways of realising or perceiving the self within the body?
Answers: Attaining the lunar light through smoke, night time, the dark fortnight, and the six months of the southern path of the sun (the southern solstice), the yogi returns.

Questions: What happens if we have only a partial or slightly incorrect knowledge of the self?
Answers: Just as the one sun illuminates the entire world, so too does the Lord of the field (Supreme Self) illuminate the entire field, O Arjuna.

Questions: What happens if we have only a partial or slightly incorrect knowledge of the self?
Answers: Among the twelve Adityas, I am Vishnu; among luminaries, the radiant sun; among the seven or forty-nine Maruts, I am Marichi; among stars, I am the moon.

Questions: What happens if we have only a partial or slightly incorrect knowledge of the self?
Answers: I see You with the diadem, club, and discus, a mass of radiance shining everywhere, very hard to look at, blazing all around like a burning fire and the sun, and immeasurable.

Questions: What happens if we have only a partial or slightly incorrect knowledge of the self?
Answers: Fire, light, daytime, the bright fortnight, the six months of the northern path of the sun (the northern solstice) departing, then men who know Brahman go to Brahman.

Questions: What happens if we have only a partial or slightly incorrect knowledge of the self?
Answers: I see You without beginning, middle, or end, infinite in power, with endless arms, the sun and moon as Your eyes, the burning fire Your mouth, heating the entire universe with Your radiance.

Questions: What happens if we have only a partial or slightly incorrect knowledge of the self?
Answers: When the wisdom-light shines through every gate of this body, then it may be known that Sattva is predominant.

Questions: What happens if we have only a partial or slightly incorrect knowledge of the self?
Answers: That which is night to all beings, in that the self-controlled man is awake; when all beings are awake, that is night for the sage who sees.

Questions: What happens if we have only a partial or slightly incorrect knowledge of the self?
Answers: With this, nourish the gods, and may the gods nourish you; thus, nourishing each other, you shall attain the highest good.

Questions: What happens if we have only a partial or slightly incorrect knowledge of the self?
Answers: Others again sacrifice all the functions of the senses and those of the breath (vital energy, or Prana) in the fire of the Yoga of self-restraint, kindled by knowledge.

Questions: What happens if we have only a partial or slightly incorrect knowledge of the self?
Answers: Self-conceited, stubborn, filled with pride and intoxication of wealth, they perform sacrifices in name only for ostentation, contrary to scriptural ordinances.

Questions: What happens if we have only a partial or slightly incorrect knowledge of the self?
Answers: Others who regulate their diet offer life-breaths in each life-breath. All these are knowers of sacrifice, whose sins are destroyed through sacrifice.

Questions: Is it possible for a human or another living being to exist without the presence of the kshetrajna or self in the body?
Answers: Serenity of mind, good-heartedness, self-control, and purity of nature—this is called mental austerity.

Questions: Is it possible for a human or another living being to exist without the presence of the kshetrajna or self in the body?
Answers: They declare that sacrifice to be Tamasic which is contrary to the ordinances of the scriptures, in which no food is distributed, and which is devoid of mantras, gifts, and faith.

Questions: Is it possible for a human or another living being to exist without the presence of the kshetrajna or self in the body?
Answers: Verily, there is no purifier in this world like knowledge. He who is perfected in Yoga finds it within the Self in due time.

Questions: Is it possible for a human or another living being to exist without the presence of the kshetrajna or self in the body?
Answers: Whatever is sacrificed, given, or performed, and whatever austerity is practiced without faith, it is called 'Asat', O Arjuna; it is of no value here or hereafter (after death).

Questions: Is it possible for a human or another living being to exist without the presence of the kshetrajna or self in the body?
Answers: In this, there is no loss of effort, nor is there any harm produced, nor any transgression. Even a little of this knowledge protects one from great fear.

Questions: Is it possible for a human or another living being to exist without the presence of the kshetrajna or self in the body?
Answers: In this, there is no loss of effort, nor is there any harm produced, nor any transgression. Even a little of this knowledge protects one from great fear.

Questions: Is it possible for a human or another living being to exist without the presence of the kshetrajna or self in the body?
Answers: Just as the embodied soul passes through childhood, youth, and old age in this body, so too does it pass into another body; the steadfast one does not grieve over this.

Questions: Is it possible for a human or another living being to exist without the presence of the kshetrajna or self in the body?
Answers: Just as the embodied soul passes through childhood, youth, and old age in this body, so too does it pass into another body; the steadfast one does not grieve over this.

Questions: Is it possible for a human or another living being to exist without the presence of the kshetrajna or self in the body?
Answers: Just as the embodied soul passes through childhood, youth, and old age in this body, so too does it pass into another body; the steadfast one does not grieve over this.

Questions: Is it possible for a human or another living being to exist without the presence of the kshetrajna or self in the body?
Answers: In the production of the effect and the cause, Nature (matter) is said to be the cause; in the experience of pleasure and pain, the soul is said to be the one responsible.

Questions: Is it possible for a human or another living being to exist without the presence of the kshetrajna or self in the body?
Answers: The body, the doer, the various senses, the different functions of various kinds, and the presiding deity—the fifth.

Questions: Is it possible to see and experience things as they truly are?
Answers: The soul seated in Nature experiences the qualities born of Nature; attachment to the qualities is the cause of its birth in good and evil wombs.

Questions: Is it possible to see and experience things as they truly are?
Answers: The Supreme Soul in this body is also called the observer, the permitter, the sustainer, the enjoyer, the great Lord, and the Supreme Self.

Questions: Is it possible to see and experience things as they truly are?
Answers: Some behold the Self within themselves through meditation, others through the Yoga of knowledge, and still others through the Yoga of action.

Questions: Is it possible to see and experience things as they truly are?
Answers: He sees, who sees that all actions are performed solely by Nature and that the Self is without action.

Questions: Is it possible to see and experience things as they truly are?
Answers: When the Lord, as the individual soul, obtains a body and when He leaves it, He takes these with Him, just as the wind takes the scents from their seats (flowers, etc.).

Questions: Is it possible to see and experience things as they truly are?
Answers: You are the primal God, the ancient Purusha, the supreme refuge of this universe, the knower, the knowable, and the supreme Abode. Through You, the universe is pervaded, O Being of infinite forms.

Questions: Is it possible to see and experience things as they truly are?
Answers: I am the source of all; from me everything evolves; Understanding this, the wise, endowed with meditation, worship me.

Questions: Is it possible to see and experience things as they truly are?
Answers: That by which one sees the indestructible Reality in all beings, not separate in any of them—know that knowledge to be Sattvic.

Questions: Is it possible to see and experience things as they truly are?
Answers: But to those whose ignorance is destroyed by knowledge of the Self, like the sun, knowledge reveals the Supreme Brahman.

Questions: Is it possible to see and experience things as they truly are?
Answers: Know that these two are the womb of all beings; thus, I am the source and dissolution of the whole universe.

Questions: Is it possible to see and experience things as they truly are?
Answers: Thus, the field, as well as knowledge and the knowable, have been briefly stated. My devotee, knowing this, enters into My being.

Questions: How can we avoid injuring our own mind?
Answers: Thus, the field, as well as knowledge and the knowable, have been briefly stated. My devotee, knowing this, enters into My being.

Questions: How can we avoid injuring our own mind?
Answers: Constancy in Self-knowledge, the perception of the end of true knowledge—this is declared to be knowledge, and what is opposed to it is ignorance.

Questions: How can we avoid injuring our own mind?
Answers: But that knowledge which sees in all beings various entities of distinct kinds as being distinct from one another, know thou that knowledge to be Rajasic.

Questions: How can we avoid injuring our own mind?
Answers: I will declare to you in full this knowledge combined with realization, after knowing which nothing else remains to be known here.

Questions: How can we avoid injuring our own mind?
Answers: He who, undeluded, knows Me as the highest Purusha, he, knowing all, worships Me with his whole being (heart), O Arjuna.

Questions: How can we avoid injuring our own mind?
Answers: Two Purushas there are in this world: the perishable and the imperishable. All beings are perishable, and the Kutastha—the unchanging—is called the imperishable.

Questions: How can we avoid injuring our own mind?
Answers: Two Purushas there are in this world: the perishable and the imperishable. All beings are perishable, and the Kutastha—the unchanging—is called the imperishable.

Questions: How can we avoid injuring our own mind?
Answers: The king of Kasi, an excellent archer, Sikhandi, the mighty car-warrior, Dhrishtadyumna, Virata, and Satyaki, the unconquered.

Questions: How can we avoid injuring our own mind?
Answers: Prowess, splendor, firmness, dexterity, and not fleeing from battle, generosity, and lordliness are the duties of the Kshatriyas, born of their own nature.

Questions: How can we avoid injuring our own mind?
Answers: Prowess, splendor, firmness, dexterity, and not fleeing from battle, generosity, and lordliness are the duties of the Kshatriyas, born of their own nature.

Questions: How can we avoid injuring our own mind?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, you praise renunciation of actions and also yoga. Please tell me conclusively which is better of the two."

Questions: Are actions done by Prakriti (nature) or by the self or soul residing in the body?
Answers: I am Kratu; I am Yajna; I am the offering to the manes; I am the medicinal herbs and all plants; I am the Mantra; I am also the ghee or melted butter; I am the fire; I am the oblation.

Questions: Are actions done by Prakriti (nature) or by the self or soul residing in the body?
Answers: Dhrishtaketu, Chekitana, the valiant king of Kasi, Purujit, Kuntibhoja, and Saibya—the best of men.

Questions: Are actions done by Prakriti (nature) or by the self or soul residing in the body?
Answers: That highest Purusha, O Arjuna, is attainable by unswerving devotion to Him alone, within Whom all beings dwell and by Whom all this is pervaded.

Questions: Are actions done by Prakriti (nature) or by the self or soul residing in the body?
Answers: Two Purushas there are in this world: the perishable and the imperishable. All beings are perishable, and the Kutastha—the unchanging—is called the imperishable.

Questions: Are actions done by Prakriti (nature) or by the self or soul residing in the body?
Answers: The Rudras, Adityas, Vasus, Sadhyas, Visvedevas, the two Asvins, Maruts, the Manus, and the hosts of celestial singers, Yakshas, demons, and the perfected ones, all look upon Thee with great amazement.

Questions: Are actions done by Prakriti (nature) or by the self or soul residing in the body?
Answers: Two Purushas there are in this world: the perishable and the imperishable. All beings are perishable, and the Kutastha—the unchanging—is called the imperishable.

Questions: Are actions done by Prakriti (nature) or by the self or soul residing in the body?
Answers: But distinct is the Supreme Purusha, called the highest Self, indestructible and Lord, who pervades the three worlds and sustains them.

Questions: Are actions done by Prakriti (nature) or by the self or soul residing in the body?
Answers: But distinct is the Supreme Purusha, called the highest Self, indestructible and Lord, who pervades the three worlds and sustains them.

Questions: Are actions done by Prakriti (nature) or by the self or soul residing in the body?
Answers: As I transcend the perishable and am even higher than the imperishable, I am declared to be the highest Purusha in the world and in the Vedas.

Questions: Are actions done by Prakriti (nature) or by the self or soul residing in the body?
Answers: That highest Purusha, O Arjuna, is attainable by unswerving devotion to Him alone, within Whom all beings dwell and by Whom all this is pervaded.

Questions: Are actions done by Prakriti (nature) or by the self or soul residing in the body?
Answers: He who, undeluded, knows Me as the highest Purusha, he, knowing all, worships Me with his whole being (heart), O Arjuna.

Questions: Is it possible to perceive Brahman or consciousness in all beings?
Answers: There are two types of beings in this world: the divine and the demoniacal. The divine has been described at length; hear from Me, O Arjuna, about the demoniacal.

Questions: Is it possible to perceive Brahman or consciousness in all beings?
Answers: Among the purifiers, I am the wind; among the warriors, I am Rama; among the fishes, I am the shark; among the streams, I am the Ganga.

Questions: Is it possible to perceive Brahman or consciousness in all beings?
Answers: Two Purushas there are in this world: the perishable and the imperishable. All beings are perishable, and the Kutastha—the unchanging—is called the imperishable.

Questions: Is it possible to perceive Brahman or consciousness in all beings?
Answers: Two Purushas there are in this world: the perishable and the imperishable. All beings are perishable, and the Kutastha—the unchanging—is called the imperishable.

Questions: Is it possible to perceive Brahman or consciousness in all beings?
Answers: The Rudras, Adityas, Vasus, Sadhyas, Visvedevas, the two Asvins, Maruts, the Manus, and the hosts of celestial singers, Yakshas, demons, and the perfected ones, all look upon Thee with great amazement.

Questions: Is it possible to perceive Brahman or consciousness in all beings?
Answers: But distinct is the Supreme Purusha, called the highest Self, indestructible and Lord, who pervades the three worlds and sustains them.

Questions: Is it possible to perceive Brahman or consciousness in all beings?

Questions: What is the use of learning to differentiate between Purusha (consciousness) and Prakriti (physical nature)?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said: Fearlessness, purity of heart, steadfastness in knowledge and yoga, almsgiving, control of the senses, sacrifice, study of scriptures, austerity, and straightforwardness.

Questions: What is the use of learning to differentiate between Purusha (consciousness) and Prakriti (physical nature)?
Answers: And he who studies this sacred dialogue of ours, by him I shall have been worshipped through the sacrifice of wisdom; such is my conviction.

Questions: What is the use of learning to differentiate between Purusha (consciousness) and Prakriti (physical nature)?

Questions: What is the use of learning to differentiate between Purusha (consciousness) and Prakriti (physical nature)?

Questions: What is the use of learning to differentiate between Purusha (consciousness) and Prakriti (physical nature)?

Questions: What is the use of learning to differentiate between Purusha (consciousness) and Prakriti (physical nature)?

Questions: What is the use of learning to differentiate between Purusha (consciousness) and Prakriti (physical nature)?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, you praise renunciation of actions and also yoga. Please tell me conclusively which is better of the two."

Questions: Does Krishna truly reveal all spiritual knowledge in the Gita?

Questions: Does Krishna truly reveal all spiritual knowledge in the Gita?

Answers: Arjuna said, "Later was Thy birth, and prior to it was the birth of Vivasvan (the Sun); how am I to understand that Thou hast taught this Yoga from the beginning?"

Questions: What happens to those who attain unity with God?

Questions: What is sattva?
Answers: The evil-doers and the deluded, who are the lowest of men, do not seek Me; those whose knowledge is destroyed by illusion follow the ways of demons.

Questions: What is sattva?
Answers: Hypocrisy, arrogance, and self-conceit, anger, harshness, and ignorance—these belong to one who is born for a demoniacal state, O Partha.

Questions: What is sattva?

Questions: What is sattva?

Questions: What is sattva?

Answers: Arjuna said, "O God, I see all the gods in Your body, as well as hosts of various classes of beings, Brahma the Lord seated on the lotus, all the sages, and the celestial serpents."

Questions: What are the effects of sattva, rajas and tamas?
Answers: Arjuna said, "Having seen this Thy gentle human form, O Krishna, now I am composed and have been restored to my own nature."

Questions: What are the effects of sattva, rajas and tamas?
Answers: Sanjaya said, Having thus spoken to Arjuna, Krishna again showed His own form. The great Soul, assuming His gentle form, then consoled Arjuna, who was terrified.

Questions: What is the sign of tamas in a person?
Answers: That person attains peace who, abandoning all desires, moves about without longing, without the sense of ownership, and without egoism.

Questions: What is the sign of tamas in a person?
Answers: Giving themselves over to immeasurable cares that end only with death, regarding the gratification of lust as their highest aim, and feeling sure that that is all.

Questions: What is the sign of tamas in a person?
Answers: Bound by a hundred ties of hope, given over to lust and anger, they strive to obtain hoards of wealth by unlawful means for sensual enjoyment.

Questions: What is the sign of tamas in a person?
Answers: Non-attachment, non-identification of the Self with son, wife, home, and the rest, and constant even-mindedness in the face of the attainment of both desirable and undesirable.

Questions: What is the sign of tamas in a person?
Answers: He attains peace into whom all desires enter, just as waters enter the ocean which, filled from all sides, remains unmoved; but not the man who is full of desires.

Answers: Filled with insatiable desires, full of hypocrisy, pride, and arrogance, holding evil ideas due to delusion, they work with impure intentions.

Questions: What is the result of sattvic action?
Answers: He who hates no creature, is friendly and compassionate to all, is free from attachment and egoism, is balanced in pleasure and pain, and is forgiving.

Questions: What is the result of sattvic action?
Answers: The wise, possessing knowledge, having abandoned the fruits of their actions, and being freed from the bonds of birth, go to the place which is beyond all evil.

Questions: What is the result of sattvic action?
Answers: He who is of the same mind towards the good-hearted, friends, enemies, the indifferent, the neutral, the hateful, the relatives, the righteous, and the unrighteous, excels.

Questions: What is the result of sattvic action?

Questions: What is the result of sattvic action?
Answers: He who neither rejoices nor hates, nor grieves nor desires, renouncing both good and evil, and who is full of devotion, is dear to Me.

He who sees the Supreme Lord existing truly in all beings, the imperishable within the perishable, sees indeed.
The deluded do not see Him who departs, stays, and enjoys; but those who possess the eye of knowledge behold Him.
Their intellect absorbed in That, their self being That, established in That, with That as their supreme goal, they go whence there is no return, their sins dispelled by knowledge.
If, filled with egoism, thou thinkest, "I will not fight," then thy resolve is vain; nature will compel thee.
Filled with insatiable desires, full of hypocrisy, pride, and arrogance, holding evil ideas due to delusion, they work with impure intentions.
Though they, with intelligence overpowered by greed, see no evil in the destruction of families and no sin in hostility to friends,
They are possessed of the deceitful nature of demons and undivine beings, filled with vain hopes, vain actions, and vain knowledge that is senseless.
He who is of the same mind towards the good-hearted, friends, enemies, the indifferent, the neutral, the hateful, the relatives, the righteous, and the unrighteous, excels.
The evil-doers and the deluded, who are the lowest of men, do not seek Me; those whose knowledge is destroyed by illusion follow the ways of demons.
Holding this view, these ruined souls of small intellect and fierce deeds come forth as enemies of the world, intent on its destruction.

Answers: Presiding over the ears, eyes, touch, taste, smell, and mind, it enjoys the objects of the senses.

Questions: What kind of sacrifice is considered tamasic?
Answers: The foods that are bitter, sour, salty, overly hot, pungent, dry, and burning are liked by the Rajasic and are productive of pain, grief, and disease.

Questions: What kind of sacrifice is considered tamasic?

Questions: What kind of sacrifice is considered tamasic?

Questions: What kind of sacrifice is considered tamasic?

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of the body?
Answers: Unsteady, vulgar, inflexible, deceitful, malicious, lazy, despondent, and procrastinating—such an agent is called Tamasic.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of the body?
Answers: The gift that is given in the wrong place and at the wrong time, to unworthy persons, without respect or with insult, is declared to be of a Tamasic nature.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of the body?
Answers: Presiding over the ears, eyes, touch, taste, smell, and mind, it enjoys the objects of the senses.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of the body?
Answers: The enjoyments that arise from contact are only sources of pain, for they have a beginning and an end, O Arjuna; the wise do not rejoice in them.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of the body?
Answers: That action which is undertaken from delusion, without regard for the consequences, loss, injury, and one's own ability, is declared to be Tamasic (dark).

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of the body?
Answers: But that which clings to one single effect as if it were the whole, without reason, without any foundation in Truth, and is trivial—that is declared to be Tamasic.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of the body?
Answers: The embodied one, having crossed beyond these three Gunas from which the body is evolved, is freed from birth, death, decay, and pain, and attains immortality.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of the body?
Answers: This space between the earth and the heavens, and all the quarters, is filled by You alone; having seen this, Your wonderful and terrible form, the three worlds are trembling with fear, O great-souled Being.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of the body?
Answers: Having seen Thy mouths fearful with teeth blazing like the fires of cosmic dissolution, I know not the four quarters, nor do I find peace. Have mercy, O Lord of the gods, O abode of the universe.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of the body?
Answers: Knowledge, action, and actor are declared in the science of the Gunas (Sankhya philosophy) to be of three kinds only, according to the distinction of the Gunas. Of these, hear duly.

Questions: What is considered to be bodily austerity?
Answers: Knowledge, action, and actor are declared in the science of the Gunas (Sankhya philosophy) to be of three kinds only, according to the distinction of the Gunas. Of these, hear duly.

Questions: What is considered to be bodily austerity?
Answers: When the seer beholds no agent other than the Gunas and knows that which is higher than them, he attains to My Being.

Questions: What is considered to be bodily austerity?
Answers: There is nothing in the three worlds, O Arjuna, that needs to be done by Me, nor is there anything unattained that needs to be attained; yet I engage Myself in action.

Questions: What is considered to be bodily austerity?
Answers: But distinct is the Supreme Purusha, called the highest Self, indestructible and Lord, who pervades the three worlds and sustains them.

Questions: What is considered to be bodily austerity?

Questions: What is considered to be bodily austerity?
Answers: Know that these two are the womb of all beings; thus, I am the source and dissolution of the whole universe.

Questions: What is considered to be bodily austerity?
Answers: O Krishna, by the prevalence of impiety, the women of the family become corrupt; and, when women are corrupted, O Varshenya (descendant of Vrishni), intermingling of castes arises.

Questions: What is considered to be bodily austerity?
Answers: Arjuna said, "What is the condition of those who, disregarding the injunctions of the scriptures, perform sacrifice with faith—is it Sattva, Rajas, or Tamas, O Krishna?"

Questions: What is considered to be bodily austerity?
Answers: Sattva attaches to happiness, Rajas to action, O Arjuna, while Tamas, verily shrouding knowledge, attaches to heedlessness.

Questions: What is considered to be bodily austerity?
Answers: The Vedas deal with the three attributes; be thou above these three attributes. O Arjuna, free yourself from the pairs of opposites and ever remain in the quality of Sattva, freed from acquisition and preservation, and be established in the Self.

Questions: What is considered to be bodily austerity?
Answers: Serenity, self-restraint, austerity, purity, forgiveness, and uprightness, as well as knowledge, realization, and belief in God, are the duties of Brahmanas, born of their own nature.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of speech?

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of speech?
Answers: From Sattva arises knowledge, and greed from Rajas; heedlessness and delusion arise from Tamas, and also ignorance.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of speech?

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of speech?

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of speech?

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of speech?

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of speech?

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of speech?
Answers: O Arjuna, bound by your own Karma (action) born of your own nature, that which from delusion you wish not to do, even that you shall do helplessly.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of the mind?

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of the mind?

Questions: What is considered to be sattvic austerity?

Questions: What is considered to be sattvic austerity?

Questions: What is considered to be sattvic austerity?

Questions: What is considered to be sattvic austerity?
Answers: How much more easily, then, do Brahmins and devoted royal saints attain the goal? Having come to this impermanent and unhappy world, do thou worship Me.

Questions: What is considered to be sattvic austerity?
Answers: When a person sees all beings as resting in the One and emanating from the One alone, they then become Brahman.

Questions: What is considered to be sattvic austerity?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "Brahman is the Imperishable, the Supreme; its essential nature is called Self-knowledge; the offering (to the gods) that causes the existence and manifestation of beings and sustains them is called action."

Questions: What is considered to be sattvic austerity?

Questions: What is considered to be sattvic austerity?
Answers: Having abandoned egoism, strength, arrogance, desire, anger, and covetousness, and being free from the notion of 'mine' and peaceful, he is fit for becoming Brahman.

Questions: What is considered to be sattvic austerity?
Answers: Those who strive for liberation from old age and death, taking refuge in Me, realize in full that Brahman, the whole knowledge of the Self, and all action.

Questions: What is considered to be sattvic austerity?

Questions: What is considered to be pure austerity?

Questions: What is considered to be pure austerity?

Questions: What is considered to be pure austerity?

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of rajas?

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of rajas?

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of rajas?
Answers: Sanjaya said: Having seen the army of the Pandavas drawn up in battle array, King Duryodhana approached his teacher, Drona, and spoke these words.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of rajas?
Answers: The king of Kasi, an excellent archer, Sikhandi, the mighty car-warrior, Dhrishtadyumna, Virata, and Satyaki, the unconquered.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of rajas?
Answers: Drona, Bhishma, Jayadratha, Karna, and other brave warriors have already been slain by Me; do not be distressed with fear; fight and you shall conquer your enemies in battle.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of rajas?
Answers: Behold the Adityas, the Vasus, the Rudras, the two Asvins, and the Maruts; behold many wonders never before seen, O Arjuna.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of rajas?
Answers: All the sons of Dhritarashtra, along with the hosts of kings of the earth, Bhishma, Drona, and Karna, as well as the chief among our warriors.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of rajas?

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of rajas?
Answers: Serene-minded, fearless, firm in the vow of a Brahmachari, having controlled their mind, thinking of Me and balanced in mind, let them sit, having Me as their supreme goal.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of rajas?
Answers: Intellect, wisdom, non-delusion, forgiveness, truth, self-restraint, calmness, happiness, pain, existence or birth, non-existence or death, fear, and also fearlessness.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of rajas?
Answers: Of these, sattva, which is luminous and healthy due to its stainlessness, binds one by attachment to happiness and knowledge, O sinless one.

Questions: What is considered to be tamasic austerity?
Answers: Harmlessness, truth, absence of anger, renunciation, peacefulness, absence of crookedness, compassion for beings, non-covetousness, gentleness, modesty, and absence of fickleness.

Questions: What is considered to be tamasic austerity?

Questions: What is considered to be tamasic austerity?

Questions: What is considered to be tamasic austerity?

Questions: What is considered to be tamasic austerity?

Questions: What is considered to be tamasic austerity?
Answers: Better is one's own duty, even if it is destitute of merits, than the duty of another well performed. He who does the duty ordained by his own nature incurs no sin.

Questions: What is considered to be tamasic austerity?
Answers: Those for whose sake we desire kingdom, enjoyments, and pleasures stand here in battle, having renounced life and wealth.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of tamas?
Answers: Better is one's own duty, though devoid of merit, than the duty of another well discharged. Better is death in one's own duty; the duty of another is fraught with fear.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of tamas?
Answers: Better is one's own duty, though devoid of merit, than the duty of another well discharged. Better is death in one's own duty; the duty of another is fraught with fear.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of tamas?
Answers: Self-conceited, stubborn, filled with pride and intoxication of wealth, they perform sacrifices in name only for ostentation, contrary to scriptural ordinances.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of tamas?
Answers: Never speak this to one who is devoid of austerities or devotion, who does not render service, who does not desire to listen, or who cavils at Me.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of tamas?
Answers: Self-conceited, stubborn, filled with pride and intoxication of wealth, they perform sacrifices in name only for ostentation, contrary to scriptural ordinances.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of tamas?
Answers: Each person devoted to their own duty attains perfection. How they attain perfection while being engaged in their own duty, hear now.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of tamas?
Answers: Among thousands of men, one may perchance strive for perfection; even among those successful strivers, only one may perchance know Me in essence.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of tamas?
Answers: With this, nourish the gods, and may the gods nourish you; thus, nourishing each other, you shall attain the highest good.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of tamas?
Answers: He from whom all the beings have evolved and by whom all this is pervaded, worshipping Him with his own duty, one attains perfection.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of tamas?
Answers: Learn from Me, O Arjuna, in brief how one who has attained perfection reaches Brahman—the Eternal, that supreme state of knowledge.

Questions: What kind of gifts are considered to be sattvic?
Answers: If you are unable to practice even this Abhyasa Yoga, be intent on doing actions for My sake; even by doing actions for My sake, you will attain perfection.

Questions: What kind of gifts are considered to be sattvic?
Answers: Man does not reach actionlessness by not performing actions; nor does he attain perfection by mere renunciation.

Questions: What kind of gifts are considered to be sattvic?

Questions: What is the threefold designation of Brahman?
Answers: Their intellect absorbed in That, their self being That, established in That, with That as their supreme goal, they go whence there is no return, their sins dispelled by knowledge.

Questions: What is the threefold designation of Brahman?

Questions: What is the best way of performing rituals?

Questions: What is the best way of performing rituals?

Questions: What is the best way of performing rituals?

Questions: What kind of knowledge is considered to be tamasic?

Questions: What kind of knowledge is considered to be tamasic?
Answers: Sanjaya said: Having seen the army of the Pandavas drawn up in battle array, King Duryodhana approached his teacher, Drona, and spoke these words.

Questions: Which action is considered to be sattvic?
Answers: Behold, O Teacher! This mighty army of the sons of Pandu, arrayed by the son of Drupada, thy wise disciple.

Questions: Which action is considered to be sattvic?
Answers: Here are heroes, mighty archers, equal in battle to Bhima and Arjuna, Yuyudhana (Satyaki), Virata, and Drupada—all mighty warriors.

Questions: Which action is considered to be sattvic?
Answers: Dhrishtaketu, Chekitana, the valiant king of Kasi, Purujit, Kuntibhoja, and Saibya—the best of men.

Questions: Which action is considered to be sattvic?
Answers: The strong Yudhamanyu and the brave Uttamaujas, the son of Subhadra (Abhimanyu, the son of Subhadra and Arjuna), and the sons of Draupadi, all of them great charioteers (great heroes)."

Questions: Which action is considered to be sattvic?
Answers: Know also, O best among the twice-born! the names of those who are the most distinguished amongst ourselves, the leaders of my army; these I name to you for your information.

Questions: Which action is considered to be sattvic?
Answers: "Thou thyself, Bhishma, Karna, Kripa, the victorious in war, Asvatthama, Vikarna, and Bhurisrava, the son of Somadatta—all these are ready for battle."

Questions: Which action is considered to be sattvic?
Answers: And also many other heroes, ready to give up their lives for my sake, armed with various weapons and missiles, all well-skilled in battle.

Questions: Which action is considered to be sattvic?
Answers: Our army, marshalled by Bhishma, is insufficient, whereas theirs, marshalled by Bhima, is sufficient.

Questions: Which action is considered to be sattvic?
Answers: Therefore, do all of you, stationed in your respective positions in the several divisions of the army, protect Bhishma alone.

Questions: Which action is considered to be sattvic?
Answers: His glorious grandsire, the oldest of the Kauravas, roared like a lion to cheer Duryodhana and blew his conch.

Questions: Which action is considered to be sattvic?
Answers: Then, suddenly, conches, kettledrums, tabors, drums, and cow horns blared forth from the Kaurava side, and the sound was tremendous.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be rajasic?
Answers: Then, Madhava (Krishna) and the son of Pandu (Arjuna), seated in the magnificent chariot yoked with white horses, blew divine conches.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be rajasic?
Answers: Hrishikesha blew the Panchajanya, Arjuna blew the Devadatta, and Bhima, the wolf-bellied doer of terrible deeds, blew the great conch Paundra.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be rajasic?
Answers: King Yudhishthira, the son of Kunti, blew the Anantavijaya; Nakula and Sahadeva blew the Sughosha and the Manipushpaka.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be rajasic?
Answers: The king of Kasi, an excellent archer, Sikhandi, the mighty car-warrior, Dhrishtadyumna, Virata, and Satyaki, the unconquered.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be rajasic?
Answers: Drupada and the sons of Draupadi, O Lord of the Earth, and the son of Subhadra, the mighty-armed, blew their conches each separately.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be rajasic?
Answers: The tumultuous sound rent the hearts of Dhritarashtra's party, reverberating through both heaven and earth.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be rajasic?
Answers: Then, seeing the people of Dhritarashtra's party standing arrayed and the discharge of weapons about to begin, Arjuna, the son of Pandu whose ensign was a monkey, took up his bow and said the following to Krishna, O Lord of the Earth.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be rajasic?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, place my chariot in the middle between the two armies, so that I may behold those who stand here, desirous to fight, and know with whom I must fight when the battle is about to commence."

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be rajasic?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, place my chariot in the middle between the two armies, so that I may behold those who stand here, desirous to fight, and know with whom I must fight when the battle is about to commence."

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be rajasic?
Answers: For I desire to observe those who are assembled here to fight, wishing to please in battle the evil-minded Duryodhana—the son of Dhritarashtra.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be rajasic?
Answers: Sanjaya said, Thus addressed by Arjuna, Krishna stationed the best of chariots, O Dhritarashtra, in the midst of the two armies.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be tamasic?
Answers: In front of Bhishma and Drona, and all the rulers of the earth, he said: "O Arjuna, son of Pritha, behold these Kurus gathered together."

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be tamasic?
Answers: Then, Arjuna (son of Pritha) saw there (in the armies) stationed fathers, grandfathers, teachers, maternal uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons, and friends.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be tamasic?
Answers: He saw fathers-in-law and friends in both the armies. The son of Kunti, Arjuna, seeing all those kinsmen thus standing arrayed, spoke sorrowfully, deeply filled with pity.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be tamasic?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, seeing my kinsmen arrayed here, eager to fight,

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be tamasic?
Answers: My limbs fail, my mouth is parched, my body quivers, and my hair stands on end.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be tamasic?
Answers: The Gandiva slips from my hand, and my skin burns all over; I am unable to stand, and my mind is reeling, as it were.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be tamasic?
Answers: And I see ill omens, O Kesava. I do not see any good in slaying my kinsmen in battle.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be tamasic?
Answers:
I desire not victory, O Krishna, nor kingdom, nor pleasures.
What use is dominion to us, O Krishna, or pleasures or even life?

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be tamasic?
Answers: Those for whose sake we desire kingdom, enjoyments, and pleasures stand here in battle, having renounced life and wealth.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be tamasic?
Answers: Teachers, fathers, sons, and grandfathers, maternal uncles, fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law, and other relatives—

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be tamasic?
Answers: These I do not wish to kill, O Krishna, even though they kill me, for the sake of dominion over the three worlds; leave alone killing them for the sake of the earth."

Questions: What kind of person is considered sattvic?
Answers: By killing these sons of Dhritarashtra, what pleasure could be ours, O Janardana? Only sin would accrue to us from killing these felons.

Questions: What kind of person is considered sattvic?
Answers: Therefore, we should not kill the sons of Dhritarashtra, our relatives; for how can we be happy by killing our own kin, O Madhava (Krishna)?

Questions: What kind of person is considered sattvic?
Answers: Though they, with intelligence overpowered by greed, see no evil in the destruction of families and no sin in hostility to friends,

Questions: What kind of person is considered sattvic?
Answers: Why should we not, who clearly see the evil in the destruction of families, learn to turn away from this sin, O Janardana (Krishna)?

Questions: What kind of person is considered sattvic?
Answers: In the destruction of a family, the immemorial religious rites of that family perish; on the destruction of spirituality, impiety indeed, overwhelms the whole family.

Questions: What kind of person is considered sattvic?
Answers: O Krishna, by the prevalence of impiety, the women of the family become corrupt; and, when women are corrupted, O Varshenya (descendant of Vrishni), intermingling of castes arises.

Questions: What kind of person is considered sattvic?
Answers: Confusion of castes leads to hell for the slayers of the family, for their forebears fall, deprived of the offerings of rice-balls and libations of water.

Questions: What kind of person is considered sattvic?
Answers: By these evil deeds of the destroyers of the family, which cause confusion of castes, the eternal religious rites of the caste and the family are destroyed.

Questions: What kind of person is considered sattvic?
Answers: We have heard, O Janardana, that those men in whose families the religious practices have been destroyed are inevitably destined to dwell in hell for an unknown period.

Questions: What kind of person is considered sattvic?
Answers: Alas! We are involved in a great sin, for we are prepared to kill our kinsmen, out of greed for the pleasures of a kingdom.

Questions: What kind of person is considered sattvic?
Answers: If the sons of Dhritarashtra, with weapons in hand, should slay me in battle, unresisting and unarmed, that would be better for me.

Questions: What kind of person is considered rajasic?
Answers: Sanjaya said, Having thus spoken in the midst of the battlefield, Arjuna cast away his bow and arrow and, his mind overwhelmed with sorrow, sat down on the seat of the chariot.

Questions: What kind of person is considered rajasic?
Answers: Sanjaya said: To him, who was thus overcome with pity, despondent, with eyes full of tears and agitated, Madhusudana (the destroyer of Madhu) or Krishna spoke these words.

Questions: What kind of person is considered rajasic?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "From whence has this perilous strait come upon you, this dejection which is unworthy of you, disgraceful, and which will close the gates of heaven upon you, O Arjuna?"

Questions: What kind of person is considered rajasic?
Answers: Do not yield to impotence, O Arjuna, son of Pritha. It does not befit you. Cast off this mean weakness of the heart! Stand up, O conqueror of foes!

Questions: What kind of person is considered rajasic?
Answers: Do not yield to impotence, O Arjuna, son of Pritha. It does not befit you. Cast off this mean weakness of the heart! Stand up, O conqueror of foes!

Questions: What kind of person is considered rajasic?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O Madhusudana, how can I fight in battle with arrows against Bhishma and Drona, who are worthy of being worshipped, O destroyer of enemies?"

Questions: What kind of person is considered rajasic?
Answers: Better it is, indeed, in this world to accept alms than to slay the most noble teachers. But if I were to kill them, even in this world, all my enjoyments of wealth and fulfilled desires would be stained with their blood.

Questions: What kind of person is considered rajasic?
Answers: I can hardly tell which would be better, that we should conquer them or that they should conquer us. Even the sons of Dhritarashtra, whom we do not wish to slay, stand facing us.

Questions: What kind of person is considered rajasic?
Answers: My heart is overpowered by the taint of pity; my mind is confused as to my duty. I ask Thee: Tell me decisively what is good for me. I am Thy disciple; instruct me, who has taken refuge in Thee.

Questions: What kind of person is considered rajasic?
Answers: I do not see that this sorrow that burns up my senses would be removed, even if I were to attain prosperous and unrivaled dominion on earth or lordship over the gods.

Questions: What kind of person is considered rajasic?
Answers: Sanjaya said: Having spoken thus to Hrishikesha, the Lord of the senses, Arjuna, the conqueror of sleep and destroyer of foes, said, "I will not fight," and became silent.

Questions: What kind of person is considered tamasic?
Answers: To him who was despondent in the midst of the two armies, Krishna, smiling, O Bharata, spoke these words.

Questions: What kind of person is considered tamasic?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "You have grieved for those who should not be grieved for; yet, you speak words of wisdom. The wise grieve neither for the living nor for the dead."

Questions: What kind of person is considered tamasic?
Answers: Nor, at any time, was I not, nor thou, nor these rulers of men; nor, verily, shall we ever cease to be hereafter.

Questions: What kind of person is considered tamasic?
Answers: Just as the embodied soul passes through childhood, youth, and old age in this body, so too does it pass into another body; the steadfast one does not grieve over this.

Questions: What kind of person is considered tamasic?
Answers: Just as the embodied soul passes through childhood, youth, and old age in this body, so too does it pass into another body; the steadfast one does not grieve over this.

Questions: What kind of person is considered tamasic?
Answers: Just as the embodied soul passes through childhood, youth, and old age in this body, so too does it pass into another body; the steadfast one does not grieve over this.

Questions: What kind of person is considered tamasic?
Answers: The contact of the senses with the objects, O son of Kunti, which causes heat and cold, pleasure and pain, has a beginning and an end; they are impermanent; endure them bravely, O Arjuna.

Questions: What kind of person is considered tamasic?
Answers: That firm man, whom surely these afflictions do not, O chief among men, to whom pleasure and pain are the same, is fit for attaining immortality.

Questions: What kind of person is considered tamasic?
Answers: That firm man, whom surely these afflictions do not, O chief among men, to whom pleasure and pain are the same, is fit for attaining immortality.

Questions: What kind of person is considered tamasic?
Answers: The unreal has no being; there is no non-being of the real; the truth about both has been seen by the knowers of the truth (or the seers of the essence).

Questions: What kind of person is considered tamasic?
Answers: Know that to be indestructible, by which all this is pervaded. No one can cause the destruction of that, the Imperishable.

Questions: What are the different kinds of buddhi?
Answers: These bodies of the embodied Self, which are eternal, indestructible, and immeasurable, are said to have an end. Therefore, fight, O Arjuna.

Questions: What are the different kinds of buddhi?
Answers: He who takes the Self to be the slayer and he who thinks it is slain, neither of them knows. It does not slay, nor is it slain.

Questions: What are the different kinds of buddhi?
Answers: It is not born, nor does it ever die; after having been, it again does not cease to be; unborn, eternal, changeless, and ancient, it is not killed when the body is killed.

Questions: What are the different kinds of buddhi?
Answers: Whoever knows it to be indestructible, eternal, unborn, and inexhaustible, how can that person slay, O Arjuna, or cause to be slain?

Questions: What are the different kinds of buddhi?
Answers: Whoever knows it to be indestructible, eternal, unborn, and inexhaustible, how can that person slay, O Arjuna, or cause to be slain?

Questions: What are the different kinds of buddhi?
Answers: Just as a man casts off worn-out clothes and puts on new ones, so too the embodied Self casts off worn-out bodies and enters others that are new.

Questions: What are the different kinds of buddhi?
Answers: Just as a man casts off worn-out clothes and puts on new ones, so too the embodied Self casts off worn-out bodies and enters others that are new.

Questions: What are the different kinds of buddhi?
Answers: Weapons cannot cut it, fire cannot burn it, water cannot wet it, wind cannot dry it.

Questions: What are the different kinds of buddhi?
Answers: This Self cannot be cut, burned, wetted, nor dried up; it is eternal, all-pervasive, stable, immovable, and ancient.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered sattvic?
Answers: This Self is said to be unmanifested, unthinkable, and unchangeable. Therefore, knowing this to be so, you should not grieve.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered sattvic?
Answers: But even if thou thinkest of It as constantly being born and constantly dying, even then, O mighty-armed one, thou shouldst not grieve.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered sattvic?
Answers: For the born, death is certain, and for the dead, birth is certain; therefore, you should not grieve over the inevitable.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered sattvic?
Answers: For the born, death is certain, and for the dead, birth is certain; therefore, you should not grieve over the inevitable.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered rajasic?
Answers: Beings are unmanifest in their beginning, manifest in their middle state, O Arjuna, and unmanifest again in their end. What is there to grieve about?

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered rajasic?
Answers: One sees this (the Self) as a wonder; another speaks of it as a wonder; another hears of it as a wonder; yet, having heard, none understands it at all.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered rajasic?
Answers: This indweller in the body of everyone is ever indestructible, O Arjuna; therefore, you should not grieve for any creature.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered rajasic?
Answers: Further, having regard to your duty, you should not waver, for there is nothing higher for a Kshatriya than a righteous war.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered rajasic?
Answers: Happy are the Kshatriyas, O Arjuna! who are called to fight in such a battle that comes of its own accord as an open door to heaven.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered rajasic?
Answers: But if you will not fight this righteous war, then having abandoned your own duty and reputation, you will incur sin.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered rajasic?
Answers: People will also recount your everlasting dishonor; and for one who has been honored, dishonor is worse than death.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered rajasic?
Answers: The great chariot-warriors will think that you have withdrawn from the battle out of fear, and you will be held in low esteem by those who have held you in high regard.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered rajasic?
Answers: Your enemies, scoffing at your power, will speak many abusive words—what could be more painful than this?

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered rajasic?
Answers: Slain, you will obtain heaven; victorious, you will enjoy the earth; therefore, stand up, O son of Kunti, resolved to fight.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered rajasic?
Answers: Having made pleasure and pain, gain and loss, victory and defeat equal, engage in battle for the sake of battle; thus, you shall not incur sin.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered tamasic?
Answers: This, which has been taught to you, is wisdom concerning Sankhya. Now listen to wisdom concerning Yoga, endowed with which, O Arjuna, you shall cast off the bonds of action.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered tamasic?
Answers: In this, there is no loss of effort, nor is there any harm produced, nor any transgression. Even a little of this knowledge protects one from great fear.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered tamasic?
Answers: In this, there is no loss of effort, nor is there any harm produced, nor any transgression. Even a little of this knowledge protects one from great fear.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered tamasic?
Answers: Here, O joy of the Kurus, there is only one single-pointed determination; many-branched and endless are the thoughts of the indecisive.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered tamasic?
Answers: The unwise, taking pleasure in the eulogizing words of the Vedas, utter flowery speech, saying, "There is nothing else," O Arjuna.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered tamasic?
Answers: Full of desires, with heaven as their goal, (they speak words that are directed to ends) leading to new births as the result of their works, and prescribe various methods abounding in specific actions, for the attainment of pleasure and power.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered tamasic?
Answers: For those who are attached to pleasure and power, whose minds are drawn away by such teachings, their determinate reason is not formed which is steadily bent on meditation and Samadhi (superconscious state).

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered tamasic?
Answers: The Vedas deal with the three attributes; be thou above these three attributes. O Arjuna, free yourself from the pairs of opposites and ever remain in the quality of Sattva, freed from acquisition and preservation, and be established in the Self.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered tamasic?
Answers: To the Brahmana who has known the Self, all the Vedas are of as much use as a reservoir of water would be in a place where there is a flood.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered tamasic?
Answers: Your right is only to work, but not to its results; do not let the results of action be your motive, nor let your attachment be to inaction.
