Answers: Among weapons, I am the thunderbolt; among cows, I am the wish-fulfilling cow called Kamadhenu; I am the progenitor, the god of love; among serpents, I am Vasuki.

Questions: Is Bhakti useful for spiritual growth?
Answers: I am Ananta among the Nagas; I am Varuna among water-deities; Aryaman among the Manes; I am Yama among the governors.

Questions: Is Bhakti useful for spiritual growth?
Answers: And I am Prahlada among the demons, I am Time among reckoners, I am the lion among beasts, and Vainateya (Garuda) among birds.

Questions: Is Bhakti useful for spiritual growth?
Answers: Among the purifiers, I am the wind; among the warriors, I am Rama; among the fishes, I am the shark; among the streams, I am the Ganga.

Questions: Is Bhakti useful for spiritual growth?
Answers: Among creations I am the beginning, the middle, and the end, O Arjuna; among the sciences, I am the science of the Self; and I am the logic among controversialists.

Questions: Is Bhakti useful for spiritual growth?
Answers: Among the letters of the alphabet, I am the letter 'A' and the dual among compounds. I am verily the inexhaustible and everlasting time; I am the dispenser of the fruits of actions, having faces in all directions.

Questions: Is Bhakti useful for spiritual growth?
Answers: And I am the all-devouring Death, and the source of prosperity for those who are to be prosperous; among the feminine qualities, I am fame, prosperity, speech, memory, intelligence, firmness, and forgiveness.

Questions: Is Bhakti useful for spiritual growth?
Answers: Among the hymns, I am the Brihatsaman; among meters, I am Gayatri; among months, I am Margasirsha; among seasons, I am the flowery season.

Questions: Is Bhakti necessary for spiritual growth?
Answers: I am the gambling of the deceitful; I am the splendor of the splendid; I am victory; I am the resolve of the resolute; I am the goodness of the good.

Questions: Is Bhakti necessary for spiritual growth?
Answers: Among the Vrishnis, I am Vaasudeva; among the Pandavas, I am Arjuna; among the sages, I am Vyasa; among the poets, I am Usanas, the poet.

Questions: Is Bhakti necessary for spiritual growth?
Answers: Of those who punish, I am the scepter; among those who seek victory, I am statesmanship; and among secrets, I am silence; I am knowledge among knowers.

Questions: Is Bhakti necessary for spiritual growth?
Answers: And whatever is the seed of all beings, that too am I, O Arjuna; there is no being, be it moving or unmoving, that can exist without Me.

Questions: Is Bhakti necessary for spiritual growth?
Answers: There is no end to My divine glories, O Arjuna, but this is a brief statement by Me of the particulars of My divine glory.

Questions: Is Bhakti necessary for spiritual growth?
Answers: Whatever being there is glorious, prosperous, or powerful, know that to be a manifestation of a part of My splendor.

Questions: Is Bhakti necessary for spiritual growth?
Answers: But, of what avail is the knowledge of all these details to you, O Arjuna? I exist, supporting this whole world with one part of Myself.

Questions: Is Bhakti necessary for spiritual growth?
Answers: Arjuna said, By this explanation of the highest secret concerning the Self which Thou hast spoken, for the sake of blessing me, my delusion has been dispelled.

Questions: Is Bhakti necessary for spiritual growth?
Answers: The origin and destruction of beings have been heard in detail from You, O lotus-eyed Lord, and also Your inexhaustible greatness.

Questions: Is Bhakti necessary for spiritual growth?
Answers: Now, O Supreme Lord, as Thou hast thus described Thyself, O Supreme Person, I wish to behold Thy divine form.

Questions: Is Bhakti necessary for spiritual growth?
Answers: If Thou, O Lord, thinkest it possible for me to see it, do Thou, then, O Lord of the Yogis, show me Thy imperishable Self.

Questions: Is God's grace required for spiritual growth?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "Behold, O Arjuna, forms of Mine, by the hundreds and thousands, of different sorts, divine, and of various colors and shapes."

Questions: Is God's grace required for spiritual growth?
Answers: Behold the Adityas, the Vasus, the Rudras, the two Asvins, and the Maruts; behold many wonders never before seen, O Arjuna.

Questions: Is God's grace required for spiritual growth?
Answers: Now, behold, O Arjuna, in this My body, the entire universe centered in one, including the moving and the unmoving, and whatever else you desire to see.

Questions: Is God's grace required for spiritual growth?
Answers: But you are not able to behold Me with these your own eyes; I give you the divine eye; behold My lordly Yoga.

Questions: Is God's grace required for spiritual growth?
Answers: Sanjaya said, Having thus spoken, O king, the great Lord of Yoga, Hari (Krishna), showed Arjuna His supreme form as the Lord.

Questions: Is God's grace required for spiritual growth?
Answers: With numerous mouths and eyes, with numerous wondrous sights, with numerous divine adornments, with numerous divine weapons uplifted, such a form He showed.

Questions: Is God's grace required for spiritual growth?
Answers: Wearing divine garlands and apparel, anointed with divine unguents, the all-wonderful, resplendent Being is endless with faces on all sides.

Questions: Is God's grace required for spiritual growth?
Answers: If the splendour of a thousand suns were to blaze out simultaneously in the sky, that would be the splendour of that mighty being.

Questions: Is God's grace required for spiritual growth?
Answers: There, in the body of the God of gods, Arjuna then saw the entire universe resting in one, with its myriad of divisions.

Questions: Is God's grace required for spiritual growth?
Answers: Then, Arjuna, filled with wonder and his hair standing on end, bowed his head to the God and spoke with palms joined.

Questions: Is God's grace required for spiritual growth?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O God, I see all the gods in Your body, as well as hosts of various classes of beings, Brahma the Lord seated on the lotus, all the sages, and the celestial serpents."

Questions: What is the concept of surrender?
Answers: I see You with boundless form on every side, with many arms, stomachs, mouths, and eyes; neither the end nor the middle nor the beginning do I see, O Lord of the Universe, O Cosmic Form.

Questions: What is the concept of surrender?
Answers: I see You with boundless form on every side, with many arms, stomachs, mouths, and eyes; neither the end nor the middle nor the beginning do I see, O Lord of the Universe, O Cosmic Form.

Questions: What is the concept of surrender?
Answers: I see You with boundless form on every side, with many arms, stomachs, mouths, and eyes; neither the end nor the middle nor the beginning do I see, O Lord of the Universe, O Cosmic Form.

Questions: What is the concept of surrender?
Answers: I see You with boundless form on every side, with many arms, stomachs, mouths, and eyes; neither the end nor the middle nor the beginning do I see, O Lord of the Universe, O Cosmic Form.

Questions: What is the concept of surrender?
Answers: I see You with the diadem, club, and discus, a mass of radiance shining everywhere, very hard to look at, blazing all around like a burning fire and the sun, and immeasurable.

Questions: What is the concept of surrender?
Answers: You are the Imperishable, the Supreme Being, worthy of being known. You are the great treasure-house of this universe; You are the imperishable protector of the eternal Dharma; You are the Primal Person, I believe.

Questions: What is the concept of surrender?
Answers: I see You without beginning, middle, or end, infinite in power, with endless arms, the sun and moon as Your eyes, the burning fire Your mouth, heating the entire universe with Your radiance.

Questions: What is the concept of surrender?
Answers: This space between the earth and the heavens, and all the quarters, is filled by You alone; having seen this, Your wonderful and terrible form, the three worlds are trembling with fear, O great-souled Being.

Questions: What is the concept of surrender?
Answers: Verily, these hosts of gods enter into Thee; some extol Thee with joined palms in fear, saying, 'May it be well!' Bands of great sages and perfected ones praise Thee with complete hymns.

Questions: What is the concept of surrender?
Answers: The Rudras, Adityas, Vasus, Sadhyas, Visvedevas, the two Asvins, Maruts, the Manus, and the hosts of celestial singers, Yakshas, demons, and the perfected ones, all look upon Thee with great amazement.

Questions: What is the concept of surrender?
Answers: Having seen Your immeasurable form with many mouths and eyes, O mighty-armed one, with many arms, thighs, and feet, with many stomachs and fearsome with many teeth, the worlds are terrified, and so am I.

Questions: Why should we surrender to God?
Answers: On seeing Thee, touching the sky, shining in many colors, with mouths wide open, with large fiery eyes, I am terrified at heart and find neither courage nor peace, O Vishnu.

Questions: Why should we surrender to God?
Answers: Having seen Thy mouths fearful with teeth blazing like the fires of cosmic dissolution, I know not the four quarters, nor do I find peace. Have mercy, O Lord of the gods, O abode of the universe.

Questions: Why should we surrender to God?
Answers: All the sons of Dhritarashtra, along with the hosts of kings of the earth, Bhishma, Drona, and Karna, as well as the chief among our warriors.

Questions: Why should we surrender to God?
Answers: Some hurry into Your mouths with their terrible teeth, fearful to behold. Some are found stuck in the gaps between the teeth, their heads crushed to powder.

Questions: Why should we surrender to God?
Answers: Verily, just as many torrents of rivers flow towards the ocean, so too these heroes in the world of men enter Thy flaming mouths.

Questions: Why should we surrender to God?
Answers: As moths hurriedly rush into a blazing fire, leading to their own destruction, so too these creatures hurry into Your mouths, leading to their own destruction.

Questions: Why should we surrender to God?
Answers: Thou lickest up, devouring all the worlds on every side with Thy flaming mouths. Thy fierce rays, filling the whole world with radiance, burn, O Vishnu!

Questions: Why should we surrender to God?
Answers: Tell me, who you are, so fierce of form. I offer my salutations to you, O God Supreme; have mercy on me. I desire to know you, the original Being. I do not indeed know your workings.

Questions: Why should we surrender to God?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "I am the full-grown, world-destroying Time, now engaged in destroying the worlds. Even without you, none of the warriors arrayed in the hostile armies will live."

Questions: Why should we surrender to God?
Answers: Therefore, stand up and obtain fame. Conquer the enemies and enjoy the unparalleled kingdom. Verily, by Me they have already been slain; be thou a mere instrument, O Arjuna.

Questions: Why should we surrender to God?
Answers: Drona, Bhishma, Jayadratha, Karna, and other brave warriors have already been slain by Me; do not be distressed with fear; fight and you shall conquer your enemies in battle.

Questions: Is God kind to his devotees?
Answers: Sanjaya said, Having heard that speech of Lord Krishna, Arjuna, with joined palms, trembling, prostrated himself, again addressing Krishna in a choked voice, bowing down, overwhelmed with fear.

Questions: Is God kind to his devotees?
Answers: Arjuna said, "It is fitting, O Krishna, that the world delights and rejoices in Your praise; demons fly in fear in all directions and the hosts of the perfected ones bow to You."

Questions: Is God kind to his devotees?
Answers: And why should they not, O great Soul, bow to Thee Who art greater than all else, the primal cause even of the Creator (Brahma), O Infinite Being, O Lord of the gods, O Abode of the universe; Thou art the imperishable, the Being, the non-being, and That which is supreme—that which is beyond the Being and the non-being.

Questions: Is God kind to his devotees?
Answers: You are the primal God, the ancient Purusha, the supreme refuge of this universe, the knower, the knowable, and the supreme Abode. Through You, the universe is pervaded, O Being of infinite forms.

Questions: Is God kind to his devotees?
Answers: You are Vayu, Yama, Agni, Varuna, the moon, the Creator, and the great-grandfather. I offer my salutations to You a thousand times, and again I offer my salutations to You.

Questions: Is God kind to his devotees?
Answers: Salutations to You in front and behind! Salutations to You on every side! O All! You, infinite in power and prowess, pervade all; therefore You are all.

Questions: Is God kind to his devotees?
Answers: Whatever I have presumptuously said from carelessness or love, addressing You as O Krishna! O Yadava! O Friend! regarding You merely as a friend, unknowing of Your greatness.

Questions: Is God kind to his devotees?
Answers: In whatever way I may have insulted You for the sake of fun, while at play, reposing, sitting, or at meals, when alone (with You), O Krishna, or in company, that I implore You, immeasurable one, to forgive.

Questions: Is God kind to his devotees?
Answers: Thou art the Father of this world, both moving and unmoving. Thou art to be adored by this world; Thou, the greatest Guru; for none exists who is equal to Thee; how then could there be another superior to Thee in the three worlds, O Being of unrivaled power?

Questions: Is God kind to his devotees?
Answers: Therefore, bowing down and prostrating my body, I crave Thy forgiveness, O adorable Lord. As a father forgives his son, a friend his dear friend, a lover his beloved, even so may Thou forgive me, O God.

Questions: Is God kind to his devotees?
Answers: I am delighted, having seen something never seen before; yet my mind is distressed with fear. Show me that form only, O God; have mercy, O God of gods, O Abode of the universe.

Questions: What happens if we do not pay heed to God?
Answers: I desire to see You as before, crowned, bearing a mace, with the discus in hand, in Your former form only, having four arms, O thousand-armed, Cosmic Being.

Questions: What happens if we do not pay heed to God?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "O Arjuna, this Cosmic Form has graciously been shown to you by Me through My own Yogic power. It is full of splendour, primeval, and infinite; this Cosmic Form of Mine has never been seen before by anyone other than you."

Questions: What happens if we do not pay heed to God?
Answers: Neither by the study of the Vedas, nor by gifts, nor by sacrifices, nor by severe austerities, can I be seen in this form in the world of men by any other than yourself, O great hero of the Kurus (Arjuna).

Questions: What happens if we do not pay heed to God?
Answers: Neither by the study of the Vedas, nor by gifts, nor by sacrifices, nor by severe austerities, can I be seen in this form in the world of men by any other than yourself, O great hero of the Kurus (Arjuna).

Questions: What happens if we do not pay heed to God?
Answers: Do not be afraid, nor be bewildered on seeing such a terrible form of Mine; with your fear dispelled and with a gladdened heart, now behold again this former form of Mine.

Questions: What happens if we do not pay heed to God?
Answers: Sanjaya said, Having thus spoken to Arjuna, Krishna again showed His own form. The great Soul, assuming His gentle form, then consoled Arjuna, who was terrified.

Questions: What happens if we do not pay heed to God?
Answers: Arjuna said, "Having seen this Thy gentle human form, O Krishna, now I am composed and have been restored to my own nature."

Questions: What happens if we do not pay heed to God?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "It is very hard indeed to see this form of Mine which thou hast seen; even the gods are ever longing to behold it."

Questions: What happens if we do not pay heed to God?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "It is very hard indeed to see this form of Mine which thou hast seen; even the gods are ever longing to behold it."

Questions: What happens if we do not pay heed to God?
Answers: Neither by the Vedas, nor by austerity, nor by gift, nor by sacrifice can I be seen in this form as thou hast seen Me so easily.

Questions: What happens if we do not pay heed to God?
Answers: But by single-minded devotion, I can be known, seen, and entered into in reality, O Arjuna.

Questions: Was it possible for Arjuna to actually give up fighting in the war?
Answers: He who does all actions for Me, who regards Me as the Supreme, who is devoted to Me, who is free from attachment, who bears no enmity towards any creature, he comes to Me, O Arjuna.

Questions: Was it possible for Arjuna to actually give up fighting in the war?
Answers: Arjuna said, "Which of them are better versed in Yoga—those who steadfastly worship You, or those who worship the imperishable and the unmanifested?"

Questions: Was it possible for Arjuna to actually give up fighting in the war?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "In My opinion, those who fix their minds on Me, worship Me ever steadfastly, and are endowed with supreme faith, are the best in Yoga."

Questions: Was it possible for Arjuna to actually give up fighting in the war?
Answers: Those who worship the imperishable, the indefinable, the unmanifest, the omnipresent, the unthinkable, the immovable, and the eternal.

Questions: Was it possible for Arjuna to actually give up fighting in the war?
Answers: Having restrained all the senses, being even-minded everywhere, and intent on the welfare of all beings, they verily come unto Me.

Questions: Was it possible for Arjuna to actually give up fighting in the war?
Answers: Greater is their trouble whose minds are set on the unmanifested, for the goal of the unmanifested is very hard for the embodied to reach.

Questions: Was it possible for Arjuna to actually give up fighting in the war?
Answers: But to those who worship Me, renouncing all actions in Me, regarding Me as the supreme goal, meditating on Me with single-minded yoga.

Questions: Was it possible for Arjuna to actually give up fighting in the war?
Answers: To those whose minds are set on Me, O Arjuna, verily I soon become the savior out of the ocean of Samsara.

Questions: Was it possible for Arjuna to actually give up fighting in the war?
Answers: Fix your mind on Me, and your intellect in Me. Then you will certainly live in Me alone hereafter.

Questions: Was it possible for Arjuna to actually give up fighting in the war?
Answers: Fix your mind on Me, and your intellect in Me. Then you will certainly live in Me alone hereafter.

Questions: Was it possible for Arjuna to actually give up fighting in the war?
Answers: Fix your mind on Me, and your intellect in Me. Then you will certainly live in Me alone hereafter.

Questions: Is there free will?
Answers: If you are unable to fix your mind steadily on Me, then seek to reach Me through the yoga of constant practice, O Arjuna.

Questions: Is there free will?
Answers: If you are unable to practice even this Abhyasa Yoga, be intent on doing actions for My sake; even by doing actions for My sake, you will attain perfection.

Questions: Is there free will?
Answers: If you are unable to do even this, then, resort to union with Me and renounce the fruits of all actions with self-control.

Questions: Is there free will?
Answers: Better indeed is knowledge than practice; better than knowledge is meditation; better than meditation is the renunciation of the fruits of actions: peace immediately follows renunciation.

Questions: Is there free will?
Answers: He who hates no creature, is friendly and compassionate to all, is free from attachment and egoism, is balanced in pleasure and pain, and is forgiving.

Questions: Is there free will?
Answers: Ever content, steady in meditation, self-controlled, possessing firm conviction, with the mind and intellect dedicated to Me, he, My devotee, is dear to Me.

Questions: Is there free will?
Answers: Ever content, steady in meditation, self-controlled, possessing firm conviction, with the mind and intellect dedicated to Me, he, My devotee, is dear to Me.

Questions: Is there free will?
Answers: He whom the world does not agitate, and who cannot be agitated by the world, and who is freed from joy, anger, fear, and anxiety—he is dear to Me.

Questions: Is there free will?
Answers: He who is free from wants, pure, expert, unconcerned, and free from pain, renouncing all undertakings and commencements, he who is devoted to Me is dear to Me.

Questions: Is there free will?
Answers: He who is free from wants, pure, expert, unconcerned, and free from pain, renouncing all undertakings and commencements, he who is devoted to Me is dear to Me.

Questions: Is there free will?
Answers: He who neither rejoices nor hates, nor grieves nor desires, renouncing both good and evil, and who is full of devotion, is dear to Me.

Questions: Is destiny more powerful than free will?
Answers: He who is the same to foe and friend, and also in honor and dishonor, who is the same in cold and heat, in pleasure and pain, and who is free from attachment.

Questions: Is destiny more powerful than free will?
Answers: He to whom censure and praise are equal, who is silent, content with anything, homeless, of a steady mind, and full of devotion; that man is dear to me.

Questions: Is destiny more powerful than free will?
Answers: They who follow this immortal Dharma, endowed with faith and regarding Me as their supreme goal, are exceedingly dear to Me.

Questions: Is destiny more powerful than free will?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "O Arjuna, this body is called the field; he who knows it is called the knower of the field by those who know them."

Questions: Is destiny more powerful than free will?
Answers: Do thou also know Me as the knower of the field in all fields, O Arjuna. Knowledge of both the field and the knower of the field is considered by Me to be the knowledge.

Questions: Is destiny more powerful than free will?
Answers: Hear from Me in brief what the field is, of what nature it is, what its modifications are, whence it is, who He is, and what His powers are.

Questions: Is destiny more powerful than free will?
Answers: Sages have sung in many ways, with various distinctive chants and also with suggestive words indicative of the Absolute, full of reasoning and decisive.

Questions: Is destiny more powerful than free will?
Answers: The great elements, egoism, intellect, and also the Unmanifested Nature, the ten senses, and one mind, and the five objects of the senses.

Questions: Is destiny more powerful than free will?
Answers: Desire, hatred, pleasure, pain, the aggregate (body), intelligence, and fortitude—the field has thus been briefly described with its modifications.

Questions: Is destiny more powerful than free will?
Answers: Humility, unpretentiousness, non-injury, forgiveness, uprightness, service to the teacher, purity, steadfastness, and self-control.

Questions: Is destiny more powerful than free will?
Answers: Indifference to the objects of the senses and also absence of egoism; perceiving the evil in birth, death, old age, sickness, and pain.

Questions: Are we free to decide what to do?
Answers: Non-attachment, non-identification of the Self with son, wife, home, and the rest, and constant even-mindedness in the face of the attainment of both desirable and undesirable.

Questions: Are we free to decide what to do?
Answers: Unswerving devotion to Me through the Yoga of non-separation, resorting to solitary places, and a distaste for the company of people.

Questions: Are we free to decide what to do?
Answers: Constancy in Self-knowledge, the perception of the end of true knowledge—this is declared to be knowledge, and what is opposed to it is ignorance.

Questions: Are we free to decide what to do?
Answers: I will declare that which is to be known, knowing which one attains immortality; the beginningless Supreme Brahman, which is neither being nor non-being.

Questions: Are we free to decide what to do?
Answers: With hands and feet everywhere, with eyes, heads, and mouths everywhere, with ears everywhere, He exists in the worlds, enveloping all.

Questions: Are we free to decide what to do?
Answers: Shining by the functions of all the senses, yet without being attached to them; unattached, yet supporting all; devoid of qualities, yet the experiencer of them.

Questions: Are we free to decide what to do?
Answers: It is within and without all beings, both the unmoving and the moving; It is subtle and unknowable, and It is near and far away.

Questions: Are we free to decide what to do?
Answers: Undivided yet, It exists as if divided in beings; It is to be known as the supporter of beings; It devours and It generates.

Questions: Are we free to decide what to do?
Answers: That Light of all lights is said to be beyond darkness: knowledge, the knowable, and the goal of knowledge, seated in the hearts of all.

Questions: Are we free to decide what to do?
Answers: Thus, the field, as well as knowledge and the knowable, have been briefly stated. My devotee, knowing this, enters into My being.

Questions: Are we free to decide what to do?
Answers: Thus, the field, as well as knowledge and the knowable, have been briefly stated. My devotee, knowing this, enters into My being.

Questions: Does God reside in all beings?
Answers: Know that Nature (matter) and the Spirit are both beginningless, and know also that all modifications and qualities are born from Nature.

Questions: Does God reside in all beings?
Answers: In the production of the effect and the cause, Nature (matter) is said to be the cause; in the experience of pleasure and pain, the soul is said to be the one responsible.

Questions: Does God reside in all beings?
Answers: The soul seated in Nature experiences the qualities born of Nature; attachment to the qualities is the cause of its birth in good and evil wombs.

Questions: Does God reside in all beings?
Answers: The Supreme Soul in this body is also called the observer, the permitter, the sustainer, the enjoyer, the great Lord, and the Supreme Self.

Questions: Does God reside in all beings?
Answers: He who thus knows the Spirit and Matter together with their qualities, in whatever condition he may be, he is not reborn.

Questions: Does God reside in all beings?
Answers: Some behold the Self within themselves through meditation, others through the Yoga of knowledge, and still others through the Yoga of action.

Questions: Does God reside in all beings?
Answers: Others, too, who do not know thus, worship, having heard of It from others; they, too, cross beyond death, regarding what they have heard as the supreme refuge.

Questions: Does God reside in all beings?
Answers: Wherever a being is born, whether unmoving or moving, know thou, O best of the Bharatas (Arjuna), that it is from the union of the field and its knower.

Questions: Does God reside in all beings?
Answers: He who sees the Supreme Lord existing truly in all beings, the imperishable within the perishable, sees indeed.

Questions: Does God reside in all beings?
Answers: For he who truly sees the same Lord dwelling everywhere does not destroy the Self by the self; rather, he attains the highest goal.

Questions: Does God reside in all beings?
Answers: He sees, who sees that all actions are performed solely by Nature and that the Self is without action.

Questions: Why should we worship God?
Answers: When a person sees all beings as resting in the One and emanating from the One alone, they then become Brahman.

Questions: Why should we worship God?
Answers: Being without beginning, devoid of any qualities, the Supreme Self, imperishable, though dwelling in the body, O Arjuna, neither acts nor is tainted.

Questions: Why should we worship God?
Answers: As the all-pervading ether is not tainted, due to its subtlety, so the Self seated everywhere in the body is not tainted either.

Questions: Why should we worship God?
Answers: Just as the one sun illuminates the entire world, so too does the Lord of the field (Supreme Self) illuminate the entire field, O Arjuna.

Questions: Why should we worship God?
Answers: They who, by the eye of knowledge, perceive the distinction between the field and its knower, as well as the liberation from the Nature of being, go to the Supreme.

Questions: Why should we worship God?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "I will again declare to thee that supreme knowledge, the best of all knowledge, having known which all the sages have gone to supreme perfection after this life."

Questions: Why should we worship God?
Answers: Those who, having taken refuge in this knowledge, have attained unity with Me, are neither born at the time of creation nor disturbed at the time of dissolution.

Questions: Why should we worship God?
Answers: My womb is the great Brahma; in it I place the germ; thence, O Arjuna, is the birth of all beings.

Questions: Why should we worship God?
Answers: Whatever forms are produced, O Arjuna, in any womb whatsoever, the great Brahma is their womb, and I am the seed-giving father.

Questions: Why should we worship God?
Answers: These qualities, O Arjuna, born of Nature, bind fast in the body of the embodied, the indestructible: purity, passion, and inertia.

Questions: Why should we worship God?
Answers: Of these, sattva, which is luminous and healthy due to its stainlessness, binds one by attachment to happiness and knowledge, O sinless one.

Questions: Why should we pray to God?
Answers: Know, O Arjuna, that Rajas is of the nature of passion, the source of thirst and attachment; it binds fast the embodied one by attachment to action.

Questions: Why should we pray to God?
Answers: But know thou Tamas to be born of ignorance, deluding all embodied beings; it binds fast, O Arjuna, through heedlessness, indolence, and sleep.

Questions: Why should we pray to God?
Answers: Sattva attaches to happiness, Rajas to action, O Arjuna, while Tamas, verily shrouding knowledge, attaches to heedlessness.

Questions: Why should we pray to God?
Answers: Now, O Arjuna, Sattva prevails, having overpowered Rajas and Tamas; then Rajas, having overpowered Sattva and Tamas; and then Tamas, having overpowered Sattva and Rajas.

Questions: Why should we pray to God?
Answers: When the wisdom-light shines through every gate of this body, then it may be known that Sattva is predominant.

Questions: Why should we pray to God?
Answers: Greed, activity, the undertaking of actions, restlessness, and longing—these arise when Rajas is predominant, O Arjuna.

Questions: Why should we pray to God?
Answers: Darkness, inertia, carelessness, and delusion—these arise when Tamas is predominant, O Arjuna.

Questions: Why should we pray to God?
Answers: If the embodied one meets death when Sattva is predominant, then they attain the spotless worlds of the knowers of the Highest.

Questions: Why should we pray to God?
Answers: Meeting death in Rajas, he is born among those who are attached to action; and dying in Tamas, he is born in the womb of the thoughtless.

Questions: Why should we pray to God?
Answers: Meeting death in Rajas, he is born among those who are attached to action; and dying in Tamas, he is born in the womb of the thoughtless.

Questions: Why should we pray to God?
Answers: They say that the fruit of good action is Sattvic and pure; indeed, the fruit of Rajas is pain, and the fruit of Tamas is ignorance.

Questions: What happens by prayer or worship?
Answers: They say that the fruit of good action is Sattvic and pure; indeed, the fruit of Rajas is pain, and the fruit of Tamas is ignorance.

Questions: What happens by prayer or worship?
Answers: They say that the fruit of good action is Sattvic and pure; indeed, the fruit of Rajas is pain, and the fruit of Tamas is ignorance.

Questions: What happens by prayer or worship?
Answers: From Sattva arises knowledge, and greed from Rajas; heedlessness and delusion arise from Tamas, and also ignorance.

Questions: What happens by prayer or worship?
Answers: From Sattva arises knowledge, and greed from Rajas; heedlessness and delusion arise from Tamas, and also ignorance.

Questions: What happens by prayer or worship?
Answers: From Sattva arises knowledge, and greed from Rajas; heedlessness and delusion arise from Tamas, and also ignorance.

Questions: What happens by prayer or worship?
Answers: From Sattva arises knowledge, and greed from Rajas; heedlessness and delusion arise from Tamas, and also ignorance.

Questions: What happens by prayer or worship?
Answers: Those seated in Sattva ascend; those of Rajasic nature dwell in the middle; and those of Tamasic nature, abiding in the function of the lowest Guna, descend.

Questions: What happens by prayer or worship?
Answers: Those seated in Sattva ascend; those of Rajasic nature dwell in the middle; and those of Tamasic nature, abiding in the function of the lowest Guna, descend.

Questions: What happens by prayer or worship?
Answers: Those seated in Sattva ascend; those of Rajasic nature dwell in the middle; and those of Tamasic nature, abiding in the function of the lowest Guna, descend.

Questions: What happens by prayer or worship?
Answers: When the seer beholds no agent other than the Gunas and knows that which is higher than them, he attains to My Being.

Questions: What happens by prayer or worship?
Answers: The embodied one, having crossed beyond these three Gunas from which the body is evolved, is freed from birth, death, decay, and pain, and attains immortality.

Questions: Was Arjuna free to decide not to fight?
Answers: Arjuna said, "What are the marks of one who has transcended the three qualities, O Lord? What is their conduct, and how do they go beyond these three qualities?"

Questions: Was Arjuna free to decide not to fight?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "When light, activity, and delusion are present, he does not hate them, nor does he long for them when they are absent.

Questions: Was Arjuna free to decide not to fight?
Answers: He who, seated like one unconcerned, is not moved by the dualities, and who, knowing that the dualities are active, is self-centered and does not move.

Questions: Was Arjuna free to decide not to fight?
Answers: Who is the same in pleasure and pain, who dwells in the Self, to whom a clod of earth, a stone, and gold are all alike, who is the same to the dear and the unfriendly, who is firm, and to whom censure and praise are one and the same.

Questions: Was Arjuna free to decide not to fight?
Answers: Who is the same in honor and dishonor, the same to friend and foe, abandoning all undertakings, he is said to have transcended the dualities.

Questions: Was Arjuna free to decide not to fight?
Answers: And he who serves Me with unwavering devotion, he, crossing beyond the dualities, is fit for becoming Brahman.

Questions: Was Arjuna free to decide not to fight?
Answers: For I am the abode of Brahman, the immortal, immutable, and everlasting Dharma, and absolute bliss.

Questions: Was Arjuna free to decide not to fight?
Answers: For I am the abode of Brahman, the immortal, immutable, and everlasting Dharma, and absolute bliss.

Questions: Was Arjuna free to decide not to fight?
Answers: For I am the abode of Brahman, the immortal, immutable, and everlasting Dharma, and absolute bliss.

Questions: Was Arjuna free to decide not to fight?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said: They (the wise) speak of the indestructible peepul tree, with its roots above and branches below, whose leaves are the meters or hymns; he who knows it is a knower of the Vedas.

Questions: Was Arjuna free to decide not to fight?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said: They (the wise) speak of the indestructible peepul tree, with its roots above and branches below, whose leaves are the meters or hymns; he who knows it is a knower of the Vedas.

Questions: Why did Krishna teach the knowledge of Yoga to Arjuna?
Answers: Its branches spread below and above, nourished by the Gunas; its buds are sense-objects, and its roots stretch forth below in the world of men, originating action.

Questions: Why did Krishna teach the knowledge of Yoga to Arjuna?
Answers: Its form is not perceived here as such, nor its end, origin, foundation, or resting place; having cut asunder this firmly rooted peepul tree with the strong axe of non-attachment.

Questions: Why did Krishna teach the knowledge of Yoga to Arjuna?
Answers: Its form is not perceived here as such, nor its end, origin, foundation, or resting place; having cut asunder this firmly rooted peepul tree with the strong axe of non-attachment.

Questions: Why did Krishna teach the knowledge of Yoga to Arjuna?
Answers: Then, that goal should be sought for, to which, having gone, none returns again. I seek refuge in that Primeval Purusha, from whence streamed forth the ancient activity or energy.

Questions: Why did Krishna teach the knowledge of Yoga to Arjuna?
Answers: Free from pride and delusion, victorious over the evil of attachment, dwelling constantly in the Self, their desires having completely turned away, freed from the pairs of opposites known as pleasure and pain, they, the undeluded, reach the eternal goal.

Questions: Why did Krishna teach the knowledge of Yoga to Arjuna?
Answers: Free from pride and delusion, victorious over the evil of attachment, dwelling constantly in the Self, their desires having completely turned away, freed from the pairs of opposites known as pleasure and pain, they, the undeluded, reach the eternal goal.

Questions: Why did Krishna teach the knowledge of Yoga to Arjuna?
Answers: Neither does the sun illuminate there, nor the moon, nor the fire; having gone there, they do not return; that is My supreme abode.

Questions: Why did Krishna teach the knowledge of Yoga to Arjuna?
Answers: An eternal portion of Myself having become a living soul in the world of life, draws to itself the five senses, with the mind as the sixth, abiding in Nature.

Questions: Why did Krishna teach the knowledge of Yoga to Arjuna?
Answers: When the Lord, as the individual soul, obtains a body and when He leaves it, He takes these with Him, just as the wind takes the scents from their seats (flowers, etc.).

Questions: Why did Krishna teach the knowledge of Yoga to Arjuna?
Answers: Presiding over the ears, eyes, touch, taste, smell, and mind, it enjoys the objects of the senses.

Questions: Why did Krishna teach the knowledge of Yoga to Arjuna?
Answers: The deluded do not see Him who departs, stays, and enjoys; but those who possess the eye of knowledge behold Him.

Questions: Why did Krishna choose Arjuna to deliver his message?
Answers: The yogis striving for perfection behold Him dwelling in the Self; but, the unrefined and unintelligent, even though striving, do not see Him.

Questions: Why did Krishna choose Arjuna to deliver his message?
Answers: That light which resides in the sun, illuminating the whole world; that which is in the moon and in the fire—know that light to be Mine.

Questions: Why did Krishna choose Arjuna to deliver his message?
Answers: Permeating the earth, I support all beings with My energy; and having become the watery moon, I nourish all herbs.

Questions: Why did Krishna choose Arjuna to deliver his message?
Answers: Having become the fire Vaisvanara, I abide in the bodies of living beings and, associated with the Prana and the Apana, digest the fourfold food.

Questions: Why did Krishna choose Arjuna to deliver his message?
Answers: And I am seated in the hearts of all; from Me come memory and knowledge, as well as their absence. I am verily That which has to be known by all the Vedas; I am indeed the author of the Vedanta and the knower of the Vedas.

Questions: Why did Krishna choose Arjuna to deliver his message?
Answers: Two Purushas there are in this world: the perishable and the imperishable. All beings are perishable, and the Kutastha—the unchanging—is called the imperishable.

Questions: Why did Krishna choose Arjuna to deliver his message?
Answers: Two Purushas there are in this world: the perishable and the imperishable. All beings are perishable, and the Kutastha—the unchanging—is called the imperishable.

Questions: Why did Krishna choose Arjuna to deliver his message?

Questions: Why did Krishna choose Arjuna to deliver his message?
Answers: But distinct is the Supreme Purusha, called the highest Self, indestructible and Lord, who pervades the three worlds and sustains them.

Questions: Why did Krishna choose Arjuna to deliver his message?
Answers: But distinct is the Supreme Purusha, called the highest Self, indestructible and Lord, who pervades the three worlds and sustains them.

Questions: Why did Krishna choose Arjuna to deliver his message?
Answers: As I transcend the perishable and am even higher than the imperishable, I am declared to be the highest Purusha in the world and in the Vedas.

Questions: What did Krishna ask Arjuna to do finally?
Answers: He who, undeluded, knows Me as the highest Purusha, he, knowing all, worships Me with his whole being (heart), O Arjuna.

Questions: What did Krishna ask Arjuna to do finally?
Answers: Thus, I have imparted to you this most secret science, O sinless one; by knowing this, one becomes wise, and all their duties are accomplished, O Arjuna.

Questions: What did Krishna ask Arjuna to do finally?
Answers: Thus, I have imparted to you this most secret science, O sinless one; by knowing this, one becomes wise, and all their duties are accomplished, O Arjuna.

Questions: What did Krishna ask Arjuna to do finally?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said: Fearlessness, purity of heart, steadfastness in knowledge and yoga, almsgiving, control of the senses, sacrifice, study of scriptures, austerity, and straightforwardness.

Questions: What did Krishna ask Arjuna to do finally?
Answers: Harmlessness, truth, absence of anger, renunciation, peacefulness, absence of crookedness, compassion for beings, non-covetousness, gentleness, modesty, and absence of fickleness.

Questions: What did Krishna ask Arjuna to do finally?
Answers: Vigor, forgiveness, fortitude, purity, absence of hatred, absence of pride—these belong to one born for a divine state, O Arjuna.

Questions: What did Krishna ask Arjuna to do finally?
Answers: Hypocrisy, arrogance, and self-conceit, anger, harshness, and ignorance—these belong to one who is born for a demoniacal state, O Partha.

Questions: What did Krishna ask Arjuna to do finally?
Answers: Hypocrisy, arrogance, and self-conceit, anger, harshness, and ignorance—these belong to one who is born for a demoniacal state, O Partha.

Questions: What did Krishna ask Arjuna to do finally?
Answers: The divine nature is deemed conducive to liberation, and the demonic to bondage. Grieve not, O Arjuna, for you are born with divine endowments.

Questions: What did Krishna ask Arjuna to do finally?
Answers: The divine nature is deemed conducive to liberation, and the demonic to bondage. Grieve not, O Arjuna, for you are born with divine endowments.

Questions: What did Krishna ask Arjuna to do finally?
Answers: There are two types of beings in this world: the divine and the demoniacal. The divine has been described at length; hear from Me, O Arjuna, about the demoniacal.

Questions: Did Krishna assure Arjuna of victory in the war?
Answers: The demoniacal do not know what to do and what to refrain from; they have neither purity, nor right conduct, nor truth.

Questions: Did Krishna assure Arjuna of victory in the war?
Answers: They say, "This universe is without truth, without a moral basis, without a God, brought about by mutual union, with lust as its cause; what else?"

Questions: Did Krishna assure Arjuna of victory in the war?
Answers: Holding this view, these ruined souls of small intellect and fierce deeds come forth as enemies of the world, intent on its destruction.

Questions: Did Krishna assure Arjuna of victory in the war?
Answers: Holding this view, these ruined souls of small intellect and fierce deeds come forth as enemies of the world, intent on its destruction.

Questions: Did Krishna assure Arjuna of victory in the war?
Answers: Filled with insatiable desires, full of hypocrisy, pride, and arrogance, holding evil ideas due to delusion, they work with impure intentions.

Questions: Did Krishna assure Arjuna of victory in the war?
Answers: Giving themselves over to immeasurable cares that end only with death, regarding the gratification of lust as their highest aim, and feeling sure that that is all.

Questions: Did Krishna assure Arjuna of victory in the war?
Answers: Bound by a hundred ties of hope, given over to lust and anger, they strive to obtain hoards of wealth by unlawful means for sensual enjoyment.

Questions: Did Krishna assure Arjuna of victory in the war?
Answers: "I have gained this today; I will fulfill this desire of mine; this is mine, and this wealth will be mine in the future."

Questions: Did Krishna assure Arjuna of victory in the war?
Answers: "I have slain that enemy, and I shall slay others too. I am the Lord; I enjoy, I am perfect, powerful, and happy."

Questions: Did Krishna assure Arjuna of victory in the war?
Answers: "I am wealthy and born into a noble family. Who is my equal? I shall perform sacrifices, give charity, and rejoice," thus deluded by ignorance.

Questions: Did Krishna assure Arjuna of victory in the war?
Answers: Bewildered by many fancies, entangled in the snare of delusion, addicted to the gratification of lust, they fall into a foul hell.

Questions: Did Krishna assure Arjuna of liberation or salvation?
Answers: Bewildered by many fancies, entangled in the snare of delusion, addicted to the gratification of lust, they fall into a foul hell.

Questions: Did Krishna assure Arjuna of liberation or salvation?
Answers: Self-conceited, stubborn, filled with pride and intoxication of wealth, they perform sacrifices in name only for ostentation, contrary to scriptural ordinances.

Questions: Did Krishna assure Arjuna of liberation or salvation?
Answers: Self-conceited, stubborn, filled with pride and intoxication of wealth, they perform sacrifices in name only for ostentation, contrary to scriptural ordinances.

Questions: Did Krishna assure Arjuna of liberation or salvation?
Answers: Given over to egoism, power, haughtiness, lust, and anger, these malicious people hate Me in their own bodies and in the bodies of others.

Questions: Did Krishna assure Arjuna of liberation or salvation?

Questions: Did Krishna assure Arjuna of liberation or salvation?
Answers: Those cruel haters, the worst among men in the world, I hurl those evil-doers into the wombs of demons only.

Questions: Did Krishna assure Arjuna of liberation or salvation?

Questions: Did Krishna assure Arjuna of liberation or salvation?

Questions: What is the core message of the Gita?
Answers: There are three gates to this hell, destructive of the self: lust, anger, and greed; therefore, one should abandon these three.

Questions: What is the core message of the Gita?
Answers: A person who is liberated from these three gates of darkness, O Arjuna, practices what is beneficial for them and thus goes to the Supreme Goal.

Questions: What is the core message of the Gita?

Questions: What is the core message of the Gita?
Answers: He who, having cast aside the ordinances of the scriptures, acts under the impulse of desire, does not attain perfection, nor happiness, nor the Supreme Goal.

Questions: What is the core message of the Gita?
Answers: Therefore, let the scripture be thy authority in determining what ought to be done and what ought not to be done. Having known what is said in the ordinance of the scriptures, thou shouldst act in this world.

Questions: What is the core message of the Gita?

Questions: What is the core message of the Gita?
Answers: Arjuna said, "What is the condition of those who, disregarding the injunctions of the scriptures, perform sacrifice with faith—is it Sattva, Rajas, or Tamas, O Krishna?"

Questions: What is the core message of the Gita?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "There are threefold faiths inherent in the nature of the embodied: the sattvic (pure), the rajasic (passionate), and the tamasic (dark). Hear of them."

Questions: What is the essence of the Gita?
Answers: The faith of each is in accordance with their nature, O Arjuna. People consist of their faith; as a person's faith is, so are they.

Questions: What is the essence of the Gita?
Answers: The faith of each is in accordance with their nature, O Arjuna. People consist of their faith; as a person's faith is, so are they.

Questions: What is the essence of the Gita?

Questions: What is the essence of the Gita?
Answers: The sattvic, or pure, men worship the gods; the rajasic, or passionate, worship the yakshas and rakshasas; the others, the tamasic or deluded people, worship ghosts and hosts of nature-spirits.

Questions: What is the essence of the Gita?

Questions: What is the essence of the Gita?
Answers: Those men who practice terrific austerities not prescribed by the scriptures, given to hypocrisy and egoism, driven by the force of lust and attachment.

Questions: What is the most important verse in the Gita?
Answers: The food that is dear to each is threefold, as well as sacrifice, austerity, and almsgiving. Hear the distinction of these.

Questions: What is the most important verse in the Gita?
Answers: The foods that increase life, purity, strength, health, joy, and cheerfulness (good appetite), which are savory, oily, substantial, and agreeable, are dear to the Sattvic (pure) people.

Questions: What is the most important verse in the Gita?
Answers: The foods that increase life, purity, strength, health, joy, and cheerfulness (good appetite), which are savory, oily, substantial, and agreeable, are dear to the Sattvic (pure) people.

Questions: What is the most important verse in the Gita?

Questions: What is the most important verse in the Gita?
Answers: The foods that are bitter, sour, salty, overly hot, pungent, dry, and burning are liked by the Rajasic and are productive of pain, grief, and disease.

Questions: What is the most important verse in the Gita?

Questions: What is the most important verse in the Gita?
Answers: That sacrifice which is offered by men without desire for reward, as enjoined by the ordinance (scripture), with a firm faith that doing so is their duty, is Sattvic or pure.

Questions: Should the knowledge of Yoga be imparted to everybody?

Questions: Should the knowledge of Yoga be imparted to everybody?
Answers: The sacrifice that is offered, O Arjuna, seeking a reward and for show, know that to be a Rajasic Yajna.

Questions: Should the knowledge of Yoga be imparted to everybody?
Answers: They declare that sacrifice to be Tamasic which is contrary to the ordinances of the scriptures, in which no food is distributed, and which is devoid of mantras, gifts, and faith.

Questions: Should the knowledge of Yoga be imparted to everybody?
Answers: Worship of the gods, the twice-born, the teachers, and the wise; purity, straightforwardness, celibacy, and non-injury are all called the austerities of the body.

Questions: Should the knowledge of Yoga be imparted to everybody?

Questions: Should the knowledge of Yoga be imparted to everybody?

Questions: Should the knowledge of Yoga be imparted to everybody?

Questions: What happens to those who spread the message of the Gita?
Answers: The austerity that is practiced with the aim of gaining good reception, honor, and worship, and with hypocrisy, is said to be Rajasic, unstable, and transient.

Questions: What happens to those who spread the message of the Gita?
Answers: The austerity that is practiced with the aim of gaining good reception, honor, and worship, and with hypocrisy, is said to be Rajasic, unstable, and transient.

Questions: What happens to those who spread the message of the Gita?
Answers: That austerity which is practised out of a foolish notion, with self-torture, or for the purpose of destroying another, is declared to be of the Tamasic nature.

Questions: What happens to those who spread the message of the Gita?
Answers: That austerity which is practised out of a foolish notion, with self-torture, or for the purpose of destroying another, is declared to be of the Tamasic nature.

Questions: What happens to those who spread the message of the Gita?
Answers: That gift which is given to one who does nothing in return, knowing it to be a duty to give in a suitable place and time to a worthy person, is held to be Sattvic.

Questions: What happens to those who spread the message of the Gita?
Answers: That gift which is given to one who does nothing in return, knowing it to be a duty to give in a suitable place and time to a worthy person, is held to be Sattvic.

Questions: What happens to those who spread the message of the Gita?
Answers: And, that gift which is given with the intention of receiving something in return, or expecting a reward, or begrudgingly, is considered to be Rajasic.

Questions: What happens to those who spread the message of the Gita?
Answers: The gift that is given in the wrong place and at the wrong time, to unworthy persons, without respect or with insult, is declared to be of a Tamasic nature.

Questions: What happens to those who spread the message of the Gita?
Answers: "Om Tat Sat": This has been declared to be the triple designation of Brahman. By that, the Brahmanas, the Vedas, and the sacrifices were created formerly.

Questions: What happens to those who spread the message of the Gita?
Answers: Therefore, with the utterance of "Om," the acts of sacrifice, gift, and austerity, as enjoined in the scriptures, are always begun by the students of Brahman.

Questions: Does God like those who serve others?
Answers: The word "Sat" is used to refer to reality and goodness; likewise, O Arjuna, the word "Sat" is used to refer to an auspicious act.

Questions: Does God like those who serve others?
Answers: Steadfastness in sacrifice, austerity, and gift is also called 'Sat', and action in connection with these, or for the sake of the Supreme, is also called 'Sat'.

Questions: Does God like those who serve others?
Answers: Whatever is sacrificed, given, or performed, and whatever austerity is practiced without faith, it is called 'Asat', O Arjuna; it is of no value here or hereafter (after death).

Questions: What happens to those who indulge in dialogue and debate about the scriptures?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O mighty-armed Hrishikesa, I desire to know the essence or truth of renunciation and abandonment severally, O slayer of Kesi."

Questions: What happens to those who indulge in dialogue and debate about the scriptures?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "The sages understand sannyasa to be the renunciation of action with desire; the wise declare the abandonment of the fruits of all actions to be tyaga."

Questions: What happens to those who indulge in dialogue and debate about the scriptures?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "The sages understand sannyasa to be the renunciation of action with desire; the wise declare the abandonment of the fruits of all actions to be tyaga."

Questions: What happens to those who indulge in dialogue and debate about the scriptures?
Answers: Some philosophers declare that actions should be abandoned as evil; while others declare that acts of sacrifice, gift, and austerity should not be relinquished.

Questions: What happens to those who indulge in dialogue and debate about the scriptures?
Answers: Hear from Me the conclusion or the final truth about this abandonment, O best of the Bharatas; abandonment, indeed, O best of men, has been declared to be of three kinds.

Questions: What happens to those who indulge in dialogue and debate about the scriptures?
Answers: Acts of sacrifice, gift, and austerity should not be abandoned, but should be performed; for sacrifice, gift, and austerity are the purifiers of the wise.

Questions: What happens to those who indulge in dialogue and debate about the scriptures?
Answers: Acts of sacrifice, gift, and austerity should not be abandoned, but should be performed; for sacrifice, gift, and austerity are the purifiers of the wise.

Questions: What happens to those who indulge in dialogue and debate about the scriptures?
Answers: But even these actions should be performed, leaving aside attachment and the desire for rewards, O Arjuna; this is my certain and most assured conviction.

Questions: What happens to those who indulge in dialogue and debate about the scriptures?
Answers: Verily, the renunciation of obligatory action is not proper; the abandonment of the same out of delusion is declared to be Tamasic.

Questions: What happens to those who indulge in dialogue and debate about the scriptures?
Answers: He who abandons action out of fear of bodily trouble (because it is painful), does not obtain the merit of renunciation by performing such Rajasic renunciation.

Questions: What happens to those who indulge in dialogue and debate about the scriptures?
Answers: Whatever obligatory action is done, O Arjuna, merely because it ought to be done, abandoning attachment and also the desire for reward, that renunciation is regarded as sattvic (pure).

Questions: Is it advisable to indulge in dialogue and debate abou the scriptures?
Answers: The man of renunciation, pervaded by purity, intelligent, and with his doubts cut asunder, does not hate an unpleasant task nor is he attached to a pleasant one.

Questions: Is it advisable to indulge in dialogue and debate abou the scriptures?
Answers: The man of renunciation, pervaded by purity, intelligent, and with his doubts cut asunder, does not hate an unpleasant task nor is he attached to a pleasant one.

Questions: Is it advisable to indulge in dialogue and debate abou the scriptures?
Answers: Indeed, it is not possible for an embodied being to completely abandon actions; however, he who relinquishes the rewards of actions is truly called a man of renunciation.

Questions: Is it advisable to indulge in dialogue and debate abou the scriptures?
Answers: Indeed, it is not possible for an embodied being to completely abandon actions; however, he who relinquishes the rewards of actions is truly called a man of renunciation.

Questions: Is it advisable to indulge in dialogue and debate abou the scriptures?
Answers: The threefold fruit of action (evil, good, and mixed) accrues after death to those who do not abandon it, but never to those who do.

Questions: Is it advisable to indulge in dialogue and debate abou the scriptures?
Answers: Learn from Me, O mighty-armed Arjuna, these five causes, as declared in the Sankhya system, for the accomplishment of all actions.

Questions: Is it advisable to indulge in dialogue and debate abou the scriptures?
Answers: The body, the doer, the various senses, the different functions of various kinds, and the presiding deity—the fifth.

Questions: Is it advisable to indulge in dialogue and debate abou the scriptures?
Answers: Whatever action a person performs with their body, speech, and mind, whether right or wrong, these five are its causes.

Questions: Is it advisable to indulge in dialogue and debate abou the scriptures?
Answers: Now, such being the case, verily he who, owing to an untrained understanding, looks upon his Self, which is isolated, as the agent, he of perverted intelligence does not see.

Questions: Is it advisable to indulge in dialogue and debate abou the scriptures?
Answers: He who is free from the egoistic notion, whose intelligence is not tainted by good or evil, though he slays these people, he does not slay, nor is he bound by the action.

Questions: Is it advisable to indulge in dialogue and debate abou the scriptures?
Answers: He who is free from the egoistic notion, whose intelligence is not tainted by good or evil, though he slays these people, he does not slay, nor is he bound by the action.

Questions: What happens to those who listen to this knowledge with faith?
Answers: Knowledge, the knowable, and the knower form the threefold impulse for action; the organ, the action, and the agent form the threefold basis of action.

Questions: What happens to those who listen to this knowledge with faith?
Answers: Knowledge, the knowable, and the knower form the threefold impulse for action; the organ, the action, and the agent form the threefold basis of action.

Questions: What happens to those who listen to this knowledge with faith?
Answers: Knowledge, action, and actor are declared in the science of the Gunas (Sankhya philosophy) to be of three kinds only, according to the distinction of the Gunas. Of these, hear duly.

Questions: What happens to those who listen to this knowledge with faith?
Answers: Knowledge, action, and actor are declared in the science of the Gunas (Sankhya philosophy) to be of three kinds only, according to the distinction of the Gunas. Of these, hear duly.

Questions: What happens to those who listen to this knowledge with faith?
Answers: That by which one sees the indestructible Reality in all beings, not separate in any of them—know that knowledge to be Sattvic.

Questions: What happens to those who listen to this knowledge with faith?
Answers: But that knowledge which sees in all beings various entities of distinct kinds as being distinct from one another, know thou that knowledge to be Rajasic.

Questions: What happens to those who listen to this knowledge with faith?
Answers: But that which clings to one single effect as if it were the whole, without reason, without any foundation in Truth, and is trivial—that is declared to be Tamasic.

Questions: What happens to those who listen to this knowledge with faith?
Answers: An action that is ordained, free from attachment, done without love or hatred, and without desire for reward is declared to be Sattvic.

Questions: What happens to those who listen to this knowledge with faith?
Answers: But that action which is done by one longing for the fulfillment of desires or gain with egotism or with much effort is declared to be Rajasic (passionate).

Questions: What happens to those who listen to this knowledge with faith?
Answers: That action which is undertaken from delusion, without regard for the consequences, loss, injury, and one's own ability, is declared to be Tamasic (dark).

Questions: What happens to those who listen to this knowledge with faith?
Answers: An agent who is free from attachment, non-egoistic, endowed with firmness and enthusiasm, and unaffected by success or failure, is considered to be of a Sattvic (pure) nature.

Questions: What did Krishna finally ask Arjuna at the end of the Gita?
Answers: Passionate, desiring to obtain the reward of their actions, greedy, cruel, impure, moved by joy and sorrow, such an agent is said to be Rajasic.

Questions: What did Krishna finally ask Arjuna at the end of the Gita?
Answers: Unsteady, vulgar, inflexible, deceitful, malicious, lazy, despondent, and procrastinating—such an agent is called Tamasic.

Questions: What did Krishna finally ask Arjuna at the end of the Gita?
Answers: Hear thou the threefold division of intellect and firmness, according to the Gunas, as I declare them fully and distinctly, O Arjuna.

Questions: What did Krishna finally ask Arjuna at the end of the Gita?
Answers: The intellect which knows the path of work and renunciation, what should be done and what should not be done, fear and fearlessness, bondage and liberation—that intellect is Sattvic (pure), O Arjuna.

Questions: What did Krishna finally ask Arjuna at the end of the Gita?
Answers: That by which one wrongly understands dharma and adharma, and also what ought to be done and what ought not to be done—that intellect, O Arjuna, is rajasic (passionate).

Questions: What did Krishna finally ask Arjuna at the end of the Gita?
Answers: That intellect, O Arjuna, which is enveloped in darkness and sees Adharma as Dharma and all things perverted, is Tamasic (dark).

Questions: What did Krishna finally ask Arjuna at the end of the Gita?
Answers: The unwavering firmness, through which Yoga restrains the functions of the mind, life-force, and senses—that firmness, O Arjuna, is Sattvic (pure).

Questions: What did Krishna finally ask Arjuna at the end of the Gita?
Answers: But that, O Arjuna, by which one holds fast to Dharma (duty), enjoyment of pleasures, and earning of wealth, on account of attachment and desire for reward—that firmness, O Arjuna, is Rajasic (passionate).

Questions: What did Krishna finally ask Arjuna at the end of the Gita?
Answers: That firmness, O Arjuna, by which a stupid man does not abandon sleep, fear, grief, despair, and conceit, is Tamasic.

Questions: What did Krishna finally ask Arjuna at the end of the Gita?
Answers: And now, O Arjuna, hear from Me of the threefold pleasure, in which one rejoices through practice and surely comes to the end of pain.

Questions: What did Krishna finally ask Arjuna at the end of the Gita?
Answers: That which is like poison at first but in the end like nectar—that happiness is declared to be sattvic, born of the purity of one's own mind due to self-realization.

Questions: Did Arjuna's delusion get destroyed?
Answers: That happiness which arises from the contact of the senses with the objects, which is initially like nectar but eventually like poison, is said to be Rajasic.

Questions: Did Arjuna's delusion get destroyed?
Answers: That happiness which at first, as well as in the end, deludes the self, and which arises from sleep, indolence, and heedlessness—that is declared to be Tamasic.

Questions: Did Arjuna's delusion get destroyed?
Answers: There is no being on earth or in heaven among the gods that is liberated from the three qualities born of Nature.

Questions: Did Arjuna's delusion get destroyed?
Answers: Of Brahmanas, Kshatriyas, Vaisyas, and Sudras, O Arjuna, the duties are distributed according to the qualities born of their own nature.

Questions: Did Arjuna's delusion get destroyed?

Questions: Did Arjuna's delusion get destroyed?

Questions: Did Arjuna's delusion get destroyed?

Questions: Did Arjuna's delusion get destroyed?

Questions: Did Sanjaya have any physical signs of emotion after completion of the Gita?
Answers: Agriculture, cattle-rearing, and trade are the duties of the Vaisya (merchant), born of their own nature; and service is the duty of the Sudra (servant-class), born of their own nature.

Questions: Did Sanjaya have any physical signs of emotion after completion of the Gita?

Questions: Did Sanjaya have any physical signs of emotion after completion of the Gita?
Answers: Each person devoted to their own duty attains perfection. How they attain perfection while being engaged in their own duty, hear now.

Questions: Did Sanjaya have any physical signs of emotion after completion of the Gita?
Answers: He from whom all the beings have evolved and by whom all this is pervaded, worshipping Him with his own duty, one attains perfection.

Questions: Did Sanjaya have any physical signs of emotion after completion of the Gita?

Questions: Did Sanjaya have any physical signs of emotion after completion of the Gita?

Questions: Did Sanjaya have any physical signs of emotion after completion of the Gita?
Answers: Better is one's own duty, even if it is destitute of merits, than the duty of another well performed. He who does the duty ordained by his own nature incurs no sin.

Questions: Did Sanjaya have any physical signs of emotion after completion of the Gita?

Questions: Did Sanjaya have any physical signs of emotion after completion of the Gita?

Questions: Did Sanjaya have any physical signs of emotion after completion of the Gita?

Questions: By whose grace did Sanjaya get to hear the Gita?

Questions: By whose grace did Sanjaya get to hear the Gita?
Answers: Learn from Me, O Arjuna, in brief how one who has attained perfection reaches Brahman—the Eternal, that supreme state of knowledge.

Questions: By whose grace did Sanjaya get to hear the Gita?
Answers: Endowed with a pure intellect, controlling the self through firmness, relinquishing sound and other objects and abandoning attraction and hatred.

Questions: By whose grace did Sanjaya get to hear the Gita?
Answers: Dwelling in solitude, eating sparingly, with speech, body, and mind subdued, always engaged in meditation and concentration, and resorting to dispassion.

Questions: By whose grace did Sanjaya get to hear the Gita?
Answers: Having abandoned egoism, strength, arrogance, desire, anger, and covetousness, and being free from the notion of 'mine' and peaceful, he is fit for becoming Brahman.

Questions: By whose grace did Sanjaya get to hear the Gita?
Answers: Becoming Brahman, serene in the Self, he neither grieves nor desires; he is the same to all beings, and obtains supreme devotion to Me.

Questions: By whose grace did Sanjaya get to hear the Gita?
Answers: By devotion, he knows Me in truth, who and what I am; then, having known Me in truth, he immediately enters into the Supreme.

Questions: By whose grace did Sanjaya get to hear the Gita?

Questions: By whose grace did Sanjaya get to hear the Gita?

Questions: By whose grace did Sanjaya get to hear the Gita?

Questions: Was Sanjaya happy after hearing the full Gita?

Questions: Was Sanjaya happy after hearing the full Gita?

Questions: Was Sanjaya happy after hearing the full Gita?

Questions: Was Sanjaya happy after hearing the full Gita?

Questions: Why was Sanjaya happy after hearing the full Gita?

Questions: Why was Sanjaya happy after hearing the full Gita?

Questions: What did Sanjaya predict about the war?
Answers: There is no one among men who does service dearer to Me, nor shall there be anyone on earth dearer to Me than him.

Questions: What did Sanjaya predict about the war?

Questions: What did Sanjaya predict about the war?
Answers: Has this been heard, O Arjuna, with one-pointed focus? Has the delusion of your ignorance been destroyed, O Dhananjaya?

Questions: What did Sanjaya predict about the war?
Answers: Arjuna said, "My delusion has been destroyed, for I have gained my knowledge (memory) through Your grace, O Krishna. I am now free from doubts. I will act according to Your word."

Questions: What did Sanjaya predict about the war?
Answers: Sanjaya said, Thus, I have heard this wonderful dialogue between Krishna and the high-souled Arjuna, which causes one's hair to stand on end.

Questions: What did Sanjaya predict about the war?
Answers: Through the grace of Vyasa, I have heard this supreme and most secret Yoga, directly from Krishna, the Lord of Yoga, Himself declaring it.

Questions: What did Sanjaya predict about the war?
Answers: O King, remembering this wonderful and holy dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna, I continually rejoice.

Questions: What did Sanjaya predict about the war?
Answers: And, remembering again and again that most wonderful form of Hari, I am filled with great wonder, O King; and I rejoice again and again.

Questions: What did Sanjaya predict about the war?
Answers: Wherever Krishna, the Lord of Yoga, is; and wherever Arjuna, the wielder of the bow, is; there is prosperity, victory, happiness, and a firm policy; this is my conviction.
